body:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Amazing.

Pros
- This is the true meaning of 'customizable'.
- You can slowly but surely buy out cities through trading, use your powwer of pink straw hats to spread your religion across the globe, or just blow it all up.
(Same goes for the other mode, you've got choices.)
- Some of your creations show up on other save files. (E.G. a spaceship belonging to a save in Space Stage abducts one of your pets in Tribal stage)
-Several 'stages'
  = Cell stage (Ever heard of Agar.io? That's what this is, but cooler.) Eat anything smaller than you. Run away from anything bigger. Have kids. Grow an extra fin. Repeat.
  = Creature stage: Grow legs and walk around. Hunt a few species to extinction. Make friends with (relative) giants. Get killed by (actual) giants.
  = Tribal stage: Kill everything that moves to death and/or hug everything that moves. (The former is much more reliable, you know.) Also: Avoid the giants.
  = Civilization Stage: A simplified version of Sid Meyer's Civilization for dummies that has been simplified, with more customizability. Watch as your trade routes get torn apart by afforementioned giants.
  = Space Stage: Make your spaceship and conquer/hug the galaxy. Destroy giants with your kickass lasers and nukes.

Cons:
- Creature stage can take FOREVER. (Due to giants.)
- One or two glitches. (Not many)
- A certain cool DLC isn't available anymore.
- The Bor- (What? Did I say Borg? I meant Grox) are overpowered, and you can't get the Genesis Dev- (*Cough cough* The staff of life *Cough cough*) because of them.

body:
Posted: January 12
												I enjoyed this game. I recommend buying the DLC for it as well though, because the Galactic Adventures DLC adds a lot. You could do without the other one though, but you might as well get it too if you have the money. 

(read no further if you don't want to know what happens as you progress.)

You start off on a planet of your choosing. From here you get to start off as a microscopic creature where you can evolve over time by either eating what I assume is algae, or other creatures. From this, paths branch off. You evolve into a mindless animal, who either tries to make friends with other creatures, fights others, or both. Then you evolve again into a tribe, where the same principles apply.  The only sad part is that you can't choose to be an underground civilization, or one that dwells in trees, underwater or on top of mountains. You can choose to give your creature wings though, if you'd like them to "fly". It's sort of just gliding, due to the fact that you can only flap your wings about 5 times or something like that.

The next stage of evolution brings you to city life, where you can either choose to dominate other nations economically, religiously, or through war. Once you've dominated all of the other nations, you advance yet again to the space stage. It's basically the same thing all over again, but in space with spaceships. That's not just it though. In space you get a variety of different missions in which you can colonize planets, eradicate diseased creatures, and even elevate tribal civilizatons!

That's not just it though. You get to create basically everything from your creature (which you can change until you get the later stages), to the buildings in which they live and work. Not only that, but you get to create their land vehicles, air vehicles, and boats. Then once you get to the space stage you get to create the spaceship model that your whole empire uses. 

If you want to play smart during the city and space stages, you can micromanage some of your cities to gain more income. Income is used to purchase vehicles during the city stage, and upgrades for your ship during the space stage. You get simple money during the city stage, but in the space stage, cities produce spice. You can sell the spices that are produced for a lot of money, if you can find the right person to sell them to.

Your goal is to reach the center of the galaxy, for who knows what might be there? But many obstacles stand in your way. Deal with them how you wish, because there are multiple ways to get there. Make friends, or dominate others to bring your rule to the whole galaxy. It's up to you. Just remember that everyone needs allies, or just really big guns. 

Lastly. The game is really monotonous in my opinion. But I like those sorts of games. If you're not a fan of monotonous tasks then you might not be a fan of this game in particular.  

Despite my annoyances with this game, I still enjoyed it a lot. Especially the missions that the DLC had to offer. I'd give this game a solid 7/10

body:
Posted: March 8
												Update! Got Spore to work with Steam now. So ignore hours played here. I've well over 600+ hours with this game since it's release quite some time ago.

So Spore is a God game of sorts, which would be ironic considering it focuses mostly on evolution for what should be the meat of the game. Depending on how you play however, it can still be a good chunk. Starting off from a tiny organism in the primordial soup, you work your way up through the food chain by consuming matter and gaining points to evolve new parts to make you more dangerous, defensive or the alpha being in the micro world. Eventually you gain the ability to have the very basic instincts of a sentient creature, growing legs and walking onto land where you proceed to evolve as before in a much larger world. From there you eventually gain a higher thought process and begin displaying the ability to form a cohesive society capable of thinking. From there you move through what's something of a crude cross between an RTS and several janky game mechanics to befriend or defeat other tribes which appear in the world. Eventually moving on to be the dominant species and begin warring with other nations which spring up. You've several ways to dominate the planet, truth be told, the mechanics behind conquering the world are the same for any path really.

And then onto the true meat of the game. Space exploration, terraforming new worlds, meeting new space empires and either kill, conquer or buy worlds from them. And then, the steam for this game begins to die down and the fun train slows substantially. Sure, at first exploring the stars is fun, but after awhile it can begin to become more of a chore to hop around space, meeting certain goals and milestones to improve your ship and empire and defending against aggressive or downright hostile space beings. I will say though, it took a long time, but your ultimate goal is to reach the center of the galaxy. I won't say what you find of course, so the truly curious will have to find their way there or just look it up online like a panzy.

Now as for the different stages of evolving a creature, a bit more in depth.

Just to note, as you progress through the stages you can choose different paths such as herbivore and carnivore which then translate into other catagories later in the game such as industrious, warlord or peaceful. All of which give some special abilities in the tribal, civilization and space stages and also effect how your creatures evolve in what parts are available in evolution.

The first two stages, cell and creature, are fairly similar in mechanics in terms of gaining DNA to evolve. The cell stage is very simple, depending on your difficulty, but typically isn't hard to get through at all. Then the creature stage which uses the same mechanics of the cell stage, but on land and much more three dimensional. The game is a bit silly in how to befriend other creatures, using silly but amusing mechanics. Combat is essentially two animals clawing at each other until one or the other is dead. This is where you begin really planning your creatures evolution a bit more. You can shape it's torso, head and any other appendage to your liking, making everything from humanoid bipedal creatures or a giant ♥♥♥♥♥ hopping around. Whatever floats your boat or finds your lost remote, weirdo.

When it comes to interacting with the world, whether it's combat or communication, it functions quite a bit like an MMO actually. You click where you want to go or use the typical WSAD keys to move around. Hotkeys, 1234 and such will perform actions depending on what you're doing with small cooldown timers. When moving on after you've gotten enough DNA, the camera mechanics and interactions perform roughly the same for the Tribal stage. This is probably the shortest stage there is. You can easily and quickly defeat or befriend other tribes and chances are it'll take about thirty or forty minutes. Operates the same with hotkeys and movement, but more like a badly formed RTS where you can move units around to collect resources and the such.

Next is the Civilization stage which is pretty bland to tell the truth. You can design your own land, water and air vehicles in just about whatever fashion you see fit. In terms of conquering, they're all pretty much the same except for trade which allows you to peacefully buy other civilizations land, but to some extent works on the same mechanics. Then you get to the true meat of the game. SPACE. And at first it's pretty amazing with how massive of a galaxy you have to explore. You'll meet a handful of different species near you, explore different planets and stars that you've seen in the sky since you first crawled onto land.

Terraforming, now there's a thing. At first it's pretty neat, slowly shaping a world to sustain life, plopping plants and animals to create a stable ecosystem so you can build colonies to populate new worlds. Along with colonizing you can collect a substance found on many planets called Spice. In this time, the most precious substance in the universe is the spice. The spice extends life. The spice expands conciousness. The spice is vital to space travel. Actually, no it's just a valuable trading commodity of different colors and rarity. You can trade spices between different systems and eventually, in most cases, be able to buy the system and aquire new planets to claim as your own.

Now things start to sort of fall apart when it comes to advancing. For a bit all these things are a bit of fun and in short bursts, it can be. However after awhile the game becomes tedious and more of a task. The expansion for the game, Galactic Adventures, does add a fairly decent amount to do, but comes across as excessively cheesy and hokey, though I imagine the target audience was a bit younger than most of the people actually playing the game or somebody at Maxis and/or EA was smoking the dank and watching far to many kids shows on Saturday morning. But a fair amount, if not almost half of other missions aren't so bad and involve a combat system which reflects what you would have experience back in the creature stage. Just with lasers and such. It does make for a less tedious but slower method to obtain Sporebucks, though you eventually reach the point where expanding your civilization, which requires massive amounts of Sporebucks to upgrade your ship. Keep it up though and this grind isn't to bad, but then you're left with even less goals to pursue as you look forward to the tedious journey to the center of the galaxy.

Oh right, your ship. Almost forgot. So you get to design a space ship of any design at the beginning of the Space stage. It doesn't matter what parts you put on it, as your ships abilities, defences and other functions are unlocked in other ways. So the design is purely aesthetic. Controls are the WSAD setup with your cursor acting as a point of aiming. Combat is usually fairly simple and becomes somewhat routine after awhile. Once you upgrade your ship enough though, combat becomes hardly a challenge and becomes more of a management thing in simply making sure your ship stays fueled and powered up.

There's not much else to say here. I will note, I remember this game being hyped up beyond belief and being a great letdown to a lot of people. I didn't feel all that disapointed, but felt there was a much greater goal this game could have accomplished rather than slowly fizzling out in its gameplay late game. I'm sure some people find the tasks entertaining for a long time, but I've found it's better in short bursts in the late game, as just about everything else can be done in a matter of six to ten hours.

So is this game with the expansions worth $40(USD)? That's a shaky yes. But if you're not willing, wait for a sale. With that, I am about to hit the maximum amount of characters available to write a rev--

												Spore is a great game with a ton of unique features that make this game differnt from the others. After playing it again and again i can say that this is a game with much replay value allowing players to experiment with differnt combinations of creature types like becoming an omnivore or becoming a waring civilization or simply making it so your species can finnacially succeed. I can also say that all the different stages add something different to the emersion of gameplay whether your managing food in tribal or designing new vehicles in the civilazation stage.The space stage may seem repetitve and tedious but not only does the rest of the game make up for it but the creators added the Galactic Adventures DLC to make things more interesting. But, as an older games there is expected to be bugs to it graphically or bugs that affect gameplay. The only major one i've come across with my crappy computer was an occasinally crash that shuts the program out. A simple solution is to simply save the game constantly. Besides that there is hours of gameplay that is fun to pick up once and a while. I suggest this to anyone who just wants to play god and screw with life. Even though it says i have only played it for a small amount of time i've been playing it on a seperate file on the DLC for over a hundred hours so listen to some of my advice.

helpfulness: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I bought this game when it was released in 2006. While Will Wright's original vision of the game was curtailed by EA's desire to rush it out, Spore has a certain charm that I love. When it came to Steam, I decided I needed to buy it again. This and the expansions are really games for people who love to create and create you can! Ships, creatures, builidings, vehicles, planets, missions, and a whole gaxaly's worth of shher fun awaits. 

It's not a "serious" space sim. You have to go into Spore with a sense of humor. It pays a loving if rather quirky tribute to Star Trek and Star Wars and other franchises - there is a HEAVY Hitchhikers CGuide to the Galaxy vibe in Spore. Now, all of that said, the base game is good, but it really shines with the Creature Cereator and goes into warp speed with GalacticAdventures. The latter expansion features on planet missions. There are both Maxis created and user created missions and they range from cute to quite frantic, violent, fast paced affairs.

I realize that Spore received mixed reviews. But bear in mind that these reviews were partly informed by the fact that Will Wright was not given time to complete his vision for this game. 

This game is a guilty pleasure for me amid all the "serious" games I play.  Spore is more of a huge creative playground and it does it better than Minecraft at least for me.

												Bought the complete pack.

Started 3 worlds.

Herbivore

Carnivore

Omnivore

Herbivore: Easy! Because in the beginning theres food LITTERALLY EVERYWHERE. On land even more! And a whole tribe collects ''Apples'' Even more!

Carnivore: Sometimes tricky, because when you are low on food you HAVE to kill a animal, even on low health.
But in the tribe stage they all go after fish, and meat. WAAAY easier. And dont be scared in the civ stage. BECAUSE BLOOD AND GLORY!!!

Omnivore:Hardest, but also easiest. Food, EVERYWHERE. All the food is accepted. But in the civ stage, Its hard to start off. First of all, Get money to make allies, start a trading route, and then, BOOM Money flows in. Buy the city, But then, Other nations attack. I can place turrets, but against a team of 7 ''Tanks'' You cant win. So i thought, If i give that city to them, then i can make a trading route with them, and buy off their city's!. Worked! after buying 7 cities, they said: Want to work together? And then, Space.

I would love a medival or pirate age. Sounds cool.


11/10 Would play it as a omnivore again.

helpfulness: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: February 5
												There is so much to love about this game. Even in its simplicity it just sucks you in and keeps you playing for hours. You really get invested in the creatures you create and early decisions have long lasting effects with such a wide variety that replayablity is endless. 

I have one major gripe with this game. There is no option for autosave. Now because of the size of the save files, it takes a few seconds to save, so I get why it was designed without autosave in mind but for the amount of complaining players have done since its release, this game should've been updated with an autosave feature as an option. The reason this bothers me so much, is because the game will occasionally crash. 

The way the game plays tends to make you forget to frequently save. Between designing your cells, later your creatures, tribes and buildings and playing with them in between, you click on a "Save and Exit" button when you finish your design but this saves your creature, not your game. And you are not able to load that creature again when you go back to an old save. I originally had this review as a do not recommend, but with some tweaking the crashes have been brought to a minimum and the amount of fun this game has to offer is just out of this world. 

Some players may be put off by the early stages and just want to put their creatures into the Space Stage of the game, but I feel that misses the point of Spore. While Spore offers you a "Creature Creator" that lets you design your creatures before you play with them, I prefer to create my creatures in the game using their history and experience to unlock DNA parts and giving them long lasting traits which result from your earliest decisions. You also get to share your creations and if logged on to the game, you will see the creatures of other players in your game as well. Overall I have to recommend this game.

body:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												If you're gonna get it, get it while it's 5 bucks. That is the price it is really worth, maybe 6. This game is a good stepping-stone for the evolution genre, and a few other indie games are following in it's path if you dig around on the internet. It's the first iteration of a still new genre. You can create a variety of your own creatures in the brilliant creature creator, and the main appeal of this is being able to see other people's creations in your world! Cool right?

Well EA has abandoned this game, so don't expect to see anything cool other than what the game developers put in there. Sometimes you can see your own creations, so that's cool.

Unfortunately, despite the variety of creatures, most of them behave the same way. You a few abilities, ranging from stealth to very limited flying. You can be a herbivore, omnivore, or carnivore.

The game has 5 stages that are all pretty different, but the game shines in Creature mode, the second stage. Where you control one creature in your species, and evolve it as it gets more sentient. Like I said before, most creatures behave the same way in Creature mode. They all hang around in their nests and hardly interact with eachother, and if they do they don't do it enough. I wanted to see creatures huntings other creatures, and bird-like creatures and bugs, but all I saw was one wandering into an aggressive territory and getting slaughtered. There is no variety of roles in the ecosystem of the game. It's just "Five Boogleborfs hanging around a nest. Kill them or sing at them?" And that's it.

 Sometimes you see "Epics" which are huge creatures, that are indeed epic. Every once in a while a world event happens, like a meteor shower or a UFO flies by. While cool, they don't mean anything.

They did a good job of making a world that looks real from far away. But get closer, and you see all sorts of flaws and places for massive improvement.

Buy it now while it's 5 bucks. Otherwise I don't recommend. Stick around, in a while "THRIVE" will come out. Look it up, it sounds good.

EDIT: It's good for kids though. I got this game when I was a little naive to the world of gaming, that's where most of my playtime come from.

body:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												Spore is a game I have played many times over the years. From the cell stage through to the space age, it keeps being fun. It is cute, appropriate for young children, can be challenging if played on harder difficulty settings, and offers you a literal galaxy's worth of content. I once spent over a year playing this game frequenly and barely put a dent in my expansion of the Universe. Making every planet mine, and every world a Tier 3 world was my dream, and the universe is so large, I don't think one person alone can do it, but it sure was fun to try. The addon content, Galactic Adventures as well as Creepy and Cute add more dimension and choice to the game, as well as some new content. One of the most exciting things about Spore is that you can create your own species at every stage, and shape them into whatever or whoever you want them to be.

helpfulness: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: February 5
												There is so much to love about this game. Even in its simplicity it just sucks you in and keeps you playing for hours. You really get invested in the creatures you create and early decisions have long lasting effects with such a wide variety that replayablity is endless. 

I have one major gripe with this game. There is no option for autosave. Now because of the size of the save files, it takes a few seconds to save, so I get why it was designed without autosave in mind but for the amount of complaining players have done since its release, this game should've been updated with an autosave feature as an option. The reason this bothers me so much, is because the game will occasionally crash. 

The way the game plays tends to make you forget to frequently save. Between designing your cells, later your creatures, tribes and buildings and playing with them in between, you click on a "Save and Exit" button when you finish your design but this saves your creature, not your game. And you are not able to load that creature again when you go back to an old save. I originally had this review as a do not recommend, but with some tweaking the crashes have been brought to a minimum and the amount of fun this game has to offer is just out of this world. 

Some players may be put off by the early stages and just want to put their creatures into the Space Stage of the game, but I feel that misses the point of Spore. While Spore offers you a "Creature Creator" that lets you design your creatures before you play with them, I prefer to create my creatures in the game using their history and experience to unlock DNA parts and giving them long lasting traits which result from your earliest decisions. You also get to share your creations and if logged on to the game, you will see the creatures of other players in your game as well. Overall I have to recommend this game.

helpfulness:

8 people found this review funny
body:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												The first thing everyone asks (or should ask) about a game is "what kind of game is it?".

Spore((tm) is, well, Spore(tm).It doesn't fit into any one genre, apart from possibly sandbox.There's no other game like it.

NOTE: Only mouse over spoilers if you feel you can handle mature content.Swear words can make your head explode if you're not careful.

When starting my Spore(tm) game, I chose a planet and a difficulty.I chose "easy", because I'm a wimp and I'd never played the game before.
Asteroids pelted the planet of my choice in a melodramatic armaggedon, making craters and levelling mountains, splashing into the oceans.

The camera zoomed in...in...in...it was deep under the ocean...an asteroid cracked open...and a sperm fused with a corn dog (spermdog?) popped out of the asteroid.

Oh wait.That's me.

I swam around, chomping up algae and chunks of unnameable meat indiscriminately, until I came across a cell far too big to be legally called a cell (you imposter!).It attempted to swallow me in its ginormous mandibles (of which it had far too many), and I could only swim away, flagella wiggling at  top speed.

Eventually I got away, and the game told me to "call a mate".I did, and my spermdog sent out a little screech, met another spermdog, and got ready for some lovin'.
To all you perverts out there: don't get your hopes up, they just dance around and lay an egg.Sexy.

I was allowed to make some tweaks to my cell's design.I gave it spikes, a third eye, and an electric butt.He then hatched from an egg cell thing.

This went on for a few minutes, until suddenly my triklopticus (for that is what I named him) grew a brain and started wishing for legs.I then advanced to the Creature stage, which consisted of adding legs to an already absurd design, and watched a dozen little leggy spermdogs run up onto dry land.

The Creature stage kept the "mating" mechanic, but I was now running around on dry land eating stuff and meeting other species.I had the option of making friends with them or eating them.

After ten minutes the ground was littered with cute little cadavers.

Eventually, the triklopticus developed into beaked scorpion-like creatures with two legs and arms I named the Ornitank.
Then they became vaguely humanoid, and when my brain had sufficiently increased in size, I moved on to the Tribe stage and was treated to a cutscene of my Ornitanks discovering fire.I was allowed to give them clothes, because they'd just invented pants, too.

This is where the game took on an Age of Empires twist.I had around six tribesmen, all living in a little hut.I could put stuff around the hut and demand that a baby be made (in which case hearts would appear around the hut, an egg would roll out the door, and hatch) and equip my tribesmen with weapons or instruments.I could put them to work hunting or gathering.

I made friends with two neighbouring villages, using the power of music, and three attacked me.Three were burnt down.
For ever village allied or destroyed, my totem pole got bigger.

Before long, my tribesmen were discussing weapons of mass destruction and plotting to take over the world.They grow up so fast *sniff*.

I designed buildings to place in my city in such a way as to increase my income and built an armada of tanks, planes, and ships (also custom designed) to conquer other cities.I gave my Ornitanks new clothes that were slightly more "civilised" (among the options I could have chosen was a large blonde moustache) and discovered that the Creature Creator had a "create animated avatar" option, so I turned my Ornitank citizen into an animated avatar.

After conquering the world, the Ornitanks turned their attention to the stars and inexplicably invented a spaceship that could go between the stars and only take a few minutes doing so (the ship, by the way, is customisable, like creatures, vehicles, and buildings).I made first contact with an alien race that ignored my ship, because they were in the middle of some kind of world war.I sucked one of them up in my tractor beam and dropped him off on my homeworld, for in the Space stage, I am a  very responsible starship captain!

I found a spacefaring race that was big and pink with one eye and a freaky mouth, who spoke to me in a high-pitched voice and asked me to eliminate the infect Doughball! to gain their allegiance (apparently Doughball! is misspelt without the exclamation mark) and so after missions from the aliens and my own race (one of which was terraforming a planet) I set up a trade route and an alliance.However, my only complaint about the space age is that after the game spends so long increasing the scale, you end up playing as a captain on a random ship.The best part is going down onto planets that aren't spacefaring and just straight-up abducting people.On top of that, you unlock crop circles and can just zap them onto planets.I kept going to Civilization Stage planets and using the crop circle tool to fuel any alien conspiracy theorists that may/may not exist.

And that is how you go from spermdog to galactic god in less than three days.

body:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a Rocky Road Bar:
1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

helpfulness: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												I love this game. I originally got the boxed version of it for Christmas a few years ago. Last year I got a new PC, and unfortunately my CD would no longer work. I am so glad that steam had this, as the steam version of this game is essentially DRM Free (Steam is the DRM in this case.) And now I can install it on as many Windows PCs as I want. Unfortunately there is no Mac version, like the boxed edition has. So if you have a Mac, you need to use the boxed version, or the origin version, which has the DRM unfortuneately. 

The only cons I can think of with this version at least, are sometimes, when you die in the creature stage, the game crashes (only happens after you move nests for the first time, but seems to stop happening once you have a big enough brain to advance to tribal.) And the game may crash when you are placing buildings in your cities in the Civilization or Space Stage. (Usually this only happens in space, when you have LARGE empire, and even then it isn't too killing. Just save before placing buildings.)

Now for a list of Pros and Cons:

Pros:
Very Robust gameplay. 5 stages, Cell, Creature, Tribe, Civilization, Space. I like each of them a lot, but I feel that the Tribe and Civilization stages are waay to short. In the Cell Stage, you are a Cell, and you need to eat, and evolve. In the Creature stage, you are a Creature, and your goal is to develop your brain, while at the same time collecting parts, and improving your Creature. The Tribe and Civilization stages play more like an RTS, and your goal is to dominate all the tribes and civilizations. In the space stage, it is essentially an open-ended sandbox, and you can do pretty much whatever you want. The only downside is you don't have unlimited money, so it isn't a TRUE sandbox.

Attention to detail. This game looks quite realistic, but still has that cartoony feel to it. The Water looks very similar to real life water, especially when the sun is reflecting off of it. Creatures, and Plants, with certain paint coats, will also have the sun reflect off of it, and it looks quite pretty. There are also Nebula, and even Supernovas (Which is just eye candy, no stars actually blow up.)

Replayability. There are 10 different archetypes in space stage, and each has a unique superpower. The possibilities to get all archetypes are practically endless. The archetypes are, Warrior, Shaman, Trader, Ecologist, Scientist, Knight, Zealot, Diplomat, Bard, and Wanderer. Each has a unique super power, and if you have galatic adventures, can obtain the other super powers via adventures, without losing your current super power. (with the exception of knights and wanderers. The Knight Super Power is impossible to acheive via galactic adventures, only through evolution. And Wanderers do not have a superpower, as that is the archetype you get for starting in space.)

Cons:

The only one I can think of is the one I listed before, where the game may crash on death in the creature stage, or when building buildings in the Civ or Space Stage. Both are minor, and as long as you save frequently, you should be okay.

Oh... and EA has abandoned this game unfortunately. They're too proud of the new Sim City, and the Sims 4 to even consider fixing this game, or making a sequel to this game, which really sucks. In America the servers for this game, are suprisingly still up, but AFAIK the European servers went down, but the Asian and Oceania servers are still up too I think.

body:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												It's fun at first, but it lacks replayability.

The cell stage is mildly entertaining while you decide what kind of life-form you want to grow up to be (though I guarantee you'll pick Omnivore if you can help it).

While it's a matter of survival in your animal form, the game really feels fresh and new. In fact, I would've liked it more if the animal stage was a lot longer. The way you interact with other animals, the way you take on larger creatures or even epic monsters, the migration patterns of your herd and exploring the wide world is really fun and really engaging.

But after the animal stage, the game becomes a very basic, very lackluster real-time strategy game. The tribal and civilization stages are nothing more than mash-ups of Age of Empires and Civilization, the only bonus being that you get to design your stuff. There's nothing here that you haven't seen before, from three-choice politics to point-and-click control of armies comprised entirely of a single land vehicle type, which you will no doubt convert to a fleet made entirely of aircraft due to them not being limited as to where they can travel.

But the biggest letdown was the space stage. Instead of starting at one vessel and working your way to commanding a whole fleet with which to explore and conquer as you see fit, you're stuck with a single ship occassionally accompanied by a few brainless AI ships who are utterly useless against the more powerful space empires and tend to die pretty quickly. Oh, sure, you can upgrade that one ship, but there's no real sense of progress being made.

The graphics aren't that great, with everything looking about as well polished as that old CG television show Reboot, just with improved animation. If the textures and shapes were a bit more complex it might stand out.

I'd recommend this game only if it's on sale or free for a weekend, because it really isn't worth paying full price for this. It has enough juice for about 1 playthrough, but afterwards I really can't see any reason to go 'round again except to make different choices that will ultimately lead to the same result. But if you take the path of least resistance, you'll end up making the same choices each time.

Ultimately, it's a good concept, but the mid-to-late game mechanics really feel uninspired, like too much focus was given to aesthetic customization options rather than gameplay mechanics.

body:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Spore has left me with very mixed emotions.  I LOVE going through the Cell stage and then playing through the Creature stage (4.5 out of 5 stars to that point).  The first night I downloaded the game, I had planned to only play a half hour or so before bed, which turned into 3+ hours and having to be harrassed by my husband to finally shut down the notebook.  I was starting to become an addict already!
And then the Tribal phase happened.
There is a very natural flow between the Cell and Creature stages, with a little more complexity added when you begin to move the camera around.  The game is entirely at your own pace and you aren't penalized for taking your time to explore, look for additional parts, or make more friends.  It's truly a casual game.  And then Tribal turns the game entirely into a Tower Defense game where you have to control multiple units and every minute you spend trying to build a strategy is held against you as the other tribes start to hate you more, attack your village, and steal your food.  To add to the fun, the interface is confusing and unintuitive.  At that point, the game fell to 3 out of 5.
I've made it through Tribal once and into the City/Civilization stage.  And that is as far as I'll ever go in this game.  The Cell and Creature stages have lots of replayability, which is why I can still recommend the game despite my obvious dislike of the rest of the stages.  I bought this game when it was on sale so I feel like it was a pretty good buy for the parts I enjoy.

body:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Spore is by far one of the best sandbox evolution based survival games I've played. Given that I haven't heard of any other games that pursue this kind of playstyle, my review may be slightly biased. You will start off as a single cell that has been brought to your planet by a meteorite. You can choose between playing as a carnivore or an herbivore. In the first stage (Cell) the carnivore is argueably the better choice because there will be plenty of creatures to eat, and you get parts to add to your cell faster this way. The currency in this stage is DNA points, which can be gained by eating plants (herbivore) or meat (carnivore). Once you have filled the progress bar to full, you will advance to the creature stage. In this stage, your cell evolved into a creature and migrates onto land with a group of your species. You are able to add legs and arms in this stage, and can add a filter mouth or jaw in order to make your species into an omnivore. I highly recommend this because you are not stuck with being forced to find animals to kill or migrate to find more fruit to eat. The currency in this stage is the same as the currency in the cell stage, however is gained by allying groups or destroying them. Once you have finished the creature stage through defeating or allying other groups of animals, you will transition to the tribal stage! In this stage you band together with your group and make alliances with other tribes or exterminate them. There is a wide array of tools available to choose from in this stage, from fishing spears, to stone axes, to healing rods. All of them serve various functions and your main currency to purchase these buildings is food. Which can either be gathered from the wild or plundered from enemy villages. Once you have finished the tribal stage, you will advance to the civilization stage! In this stage, the tribes you either destroyed or allied will band together to form your first city! You get to design a lot in this stage. The town hall, factories, houses, entertainment, boats, cars, airplanes! It's all at your fingertips! The main currency in this stage is called Sporebucks. This is earned by selling spice, the hot commodity in spore, which is produced by geysers on your planet. Eventually, other groups of your species will arise with their own cities. You can either choose to ally them, purchase their city through economic means, convert their city through religious means, or force their city into submission through military means. How you played each stage determines which kinds of special abilities that you have. In the civilization stage, the way you played the tribal stage determines whether you are a militant or religious city. How you caputure an enemy city determines its specialization. Or for instance you capture a military city by religious means, you can choose whether it is a military city or a religious city. Once you have achieved total global domination, you will advance to the space stage! Most people dislike the space stage because it's "boring" or "too different from previous stages". I think it is the most fun stage because you can purchase star systems, plant colonies, craft planets to your liking, discover other empires, destroy lesser empires, uplift a species in a lower stage to a higher one, terraform planets that were 150 degrees Celsious to a comfortable 22 degrees, control the spice empire through taking ownership of the high profit spice planets, defeat the evil Grox empire guarding the center of the galaxy, and so much more! People dislike it because it takes so long, but that's the fun of it. You are but a single planet in a galaxy of tens of thousands! Have fun, explore! They've even included the Solar System for you to find (I've found it)! After playing this game for over a week now, I've expanded my empire to a measly 30ish systems. I look forward to conquering the Grox and expanding my fruitful empire to the farthest reaches of the galaxy.

tl;dr A great game with tons of customization as you expand from a cell to a galactic superpower.

10/10

Posted: March 21
												I play this game all the time and it never ever gets boring.My friends and I enjoy competeing to see who can make the most creepiest or cutest creature.
 Anyways about the game,Spore is a very fun and creative game to play.Many achevments can be unlocked and you can even set you own goals.The game is more on the lines of solo than multiplayer,but it would be cool if you could visit other people's planets and creatures.The game is basically a great game where you can create you own creatures and make them go through evolotion.
Their are alot of pros I can think of but thankfully not many cons.Here are some:
Pros:
1. Very positive
2. Entertaining
3. Creative
4. Never ends (As in their are no limits to how many creatures,planet,or games you can make.)
Cons:
1. Addicting
2. Not multiplayer (Although I'm hoping it will be in the future.)

 Well there are the pros and cons of the game Spore! I hop you found this review useful if you are interested in the game.And if you do buy it and try it,I hope you will enjoy it as much as I do!

									Product received for free

												Now, I know this things says I have not played long. True. At least not on steam. I have played this game a TON with the CD version of the game. I love how much creativity you can apply to making your creature. I mean, if you want to give your either cute and lovable creature or your horrifying nightmare-inducing monstrosity a documetary-style description, you can do that! Depending on how you play during each stage of the game can decide what abilities you have to work with for the next, and you can even control this by looking at the evolution history to help you steer toward the path you want to take, whether you want to be a peacful dancing species or be that person who says "I WILL DESTROY YOU ALL!" and be completley evil (this is the route i like most). Or you could be both. Theres also that option. You can also throw things at other creatures which can surprise them as well as make them dizzy. 
Anyway, I highly recomend this game as you can choose how you want to play and know when youre going too far in the opposite direction as well as how fun the game is in general.

body:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Okay....soo I am reviewing this from when I played it many years ago shortly after it came out on PC. At the time I remember looking this game up and seeing its promise for a in-depth evolution system which seemed almost too complicated for me to understand but sure looked fun as hell~

So I got it on a CD at some point and I remember playing it all night and day. It was a few weeks before I stopped but while playing it I felt like it was missing something, like I was playing half of the game that was promised. At the time I was on end-game stuff which is the spaceship stage (which pretty much never ends). So I started to realize it isn't really complicated and in-depth as it was promised to be. It seems more basic and nothing super advanced.... but I still loved it. Its a shame though because it could of still been something much MUCH bigger if it had more depth. Also apparently some of the Sport EA servers are shut down now so there isn't much of a community for the game now.

To keep it short...the game is really fun if you like a mixture of RPG, Sims, Strategy games with heavy customization to keep it personal and unique to every person. I highly recommend this game still even if it is a bit dull around the edges.

helpfulness: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												TL;DR : This is not a game; it's an environment in which you can admire your creature-making and vehicle-making skills in cool situations.  It's very repetetive, but the scope of the game allows for it to be somehow addictive once you reach the space-age.  So yeah, it's great for very casual gamers, but anyone who wants to experience interesting gameplay will find this game lacking.  Pick it up if it's a couple quid, but I wouldn't pay full-price for it.  Also, ignore the expansion packs.

This isn't really one cohesive game, but a series of mini-games, so I'll just review each one seperately:

Cellular Stage: 
No fun at all, but it's designed as a tutorial to introduce you to the creature-creation and DNA mechanics; swim towards stuff in 2D to get points once your creature auto-eats it - other creatures for 'bad'/'carnivore' points, plants for 'good'/'herbivore' points; a mixture for 'neutral'/'omnivore' points.

Creature Stage: 
Like the cellular stage, but 3D, and to get the 'good' points, you have to sing, dance and pose your way into getting other creatures to like you.  Creature customisation gets real here and you spend most of your time wandering around picking up skeletons to unlock new parts.  This is the most boring stage IMHO due to it's repetition.

Tribal Stage: 
Exactly like the creature stage apart from instead of unlocking new parts, you unlock buildings to give you weapons to kill, or instruments to win over other tribes; it's only less boring than the creature stage because it passes much more quickly.

Civilisation Stage:
The overall point of this stage is the same as the tribal stage, but you also get to design vehicles (land / sea / air) and buildings - as the modelling is the most fun part of the whole game, this is real fun.  You have a -little- bit of resource management as when you're putting the buildings in your city, there's an optimal pattern. It also introduces the 'diplomacy' mechanic which is basically 'get people to like you by giving them money, and then ask them to give you everything they own'.  This bit goes by in a flash, but that's good because the most fun part is...

Space Stage:
This is basically where you apply everything at once - you build spaceships, buildings, vehicles, and even new creatures (once you get the 'creature tweaker' tool for your spaceship).  You can basically take over the whole galaxy by terraforming each planet and putting down colonies...which is fun and satisfying for the first few times, but once you get your first million bucks everything becomes VERY easy and the game stops being fun to play.  

It doesn't stop being addictive, however, because you still find yourself saying things like "If I make my main spaceship look like a star destroyer, can I try and befriend every other alien race who's ships are TIE-fighters so I can fly around with an Imperial fleet?" and you spend the next several hours exploring the galaxy finding / uplifting new races; or you set yourself the task of entirely wiping out the 'big bad' Grox...which I think is impossible, but still.

So yeah, I mean...it's a really great casual game, but if you're after any depth at all you will end up disappointed.  It is very cool flying around in an X-Wing though, and painting every planet white...and setting the ground units to imperial walkers and the air-units to Snow Speeders so you can re-enact the battle of Hoth...

helpfulness: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												A long time ago I dreamt of getting this game as a kid, so many years later I finally got my hands on it and it's even more fun than I expected.  Getting to see your creation evolve from a single cell all the way to a galactic ruler is truly a special experience.  I also find that there is a lot of replay value in this game, I always come back to see what kind or route or creature I can make this time.  If you have an active imagination begging to be let loose on a sandbox world and are willing to challenge yourself to work around the constraints nature has placed on you, then this is the game for you.  Even if you're looking for a more relaxing time, there's an evolutionary stage for everyone.  Keep in mind I have no idea what this game was supposed to be and am only judging it from what I got.  Could this game have turned out better?  Yes.  Is it still fun? Yes. Is it worth the price?  Yes.

												It only took me 8 years to play it... yes, get it. You can feel the quality, it's a powerful game, every phase is new and well done and the progression feels great. It might feel short after the first playthrough though.
I have no idea if the online features work and I don't really care. There are minor bugs and problems with the AI, for example in tribal stage when gathering food, but playing around with your own creations makes more than up for it. 
For example: you may see your ship from the other playthrough abducting other creatures or crashed in some random planet... The end game, in space, it's an almost endless sandbox to play in. I like it, every game should have this.

tl;dr Great replay value, great game, complex but inviting.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												Since I've played a little bit, let me tell you why it's awesome:
 In General The game has multiple stages: Cell stage, Creature Stage, Tribal Stage, Civilization Stage, and Space stage.
 You can make friends and enemies
 YOU CAN KILL EVERYONE
 You can befriend everyone <3 (at least until you get into the civ stage, where everyone hates you)
 The video above this review makes this game look nothing like it actually is.
 3 Different levels of difficulties: Easy, Normal, and Hard. 
 Cell stage  EAT  EVERYTHING  AS AN OMNIVORE. EVERYTHIIING!!!! 
*OR*
 Eat just plants as an herbivore.
 Eat just meat as a carnivore
 What you decide to eat is what you eat for the rest of the game. You can also put on herbivore and carnivore mouths on to eat things other than what you mostly ate in the cell stage
 BECOME THE MOST MONSTROUS SPERM CELL TO EVER EXIST
 Eat things for DNA points.
 Creature Stage  ♥♥♥♥♥ monsters.
 You can literally make almost anything you want.
 Kill things or socialize with things for dna points to customize your creature.
 Tribal Stage SPOILER  IF YOU PLAY THIS ON A CARNIVORE RUN ON HARD, PREPARE YOUR ♥♥♥♥ FOR A LONG GAME OF WAR
 Food is the new DNA. Run out of food and you're screwed.  I'm almost certain that being an herbivore is easier
 Kill people and destroy their tribes to add to your totem pole
 Befriend people and add them to your totem pole
 Hate everyone because they are ALWAYS ♥♥♥♥ING ATTACKING YOU

 Civilization Stage  Laugh at everyone when you destroy or take over their cities
 Laugh at everyone who accepts your cheap buy offers
 Hate every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ military city
 Place building in your cities in any way you want to. 
 Space Stage  Have no idea what you are doing
 Find out what to do
 Become the second largest empire in the galaxy
 Have more money than you know what to do with
 Kill everyone
 Befriend everyone
Thats about all I have to say about this game. Enjoy!

I enjoyed the game as a child, and perhaps that is who would get the most enjoyment out of this game.

body:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I wish everyone a merry Christmas, but that´s not the full purpose of this review.

I discovered SPORE in 2012, more than 4 years ago and I can still enjoy it like I did then. This game isn´t only one of my all-time favourites, but my secondly most played game of all time as well. As you can see on my playtime, SPORE is absolutely massive and I don´t regret any minute I spent on it, not even those 2,880+ I had already collected on Origin. I am thankful this is now also available on Steam, but unfortunately EA games are simply not made to be here, EA doesn´t give a **** to their Steam-community.

Whom do I recommend SPORE to? 
(All following aspects are listed in order of importance)

Explorers: First spot, definately. If you love to spend your time on uncovering secrets, this game is perfect. Especially the last stage has tons of things waiting to be discovered by YOU. If you aren´t an explorer, don´t be afraid, this one is OPTIONAL, you can "complete" SPORE without finding all secrets as well.

Creative: Very close to the previous type. The designers feature nearly INFINITE possibilities. There´s almost nothing you can´t create, your imagination is the only limit. More than 400 Creature-, 500 Vehicle- and 600 Building-parts to use, modifacation of those and no set placements allow an unbelievable ammount of possible combinations. In fact there is no object looking like another one.

"God-wannabes": Write your own story from the very beginning. Start as nothing but a little cell, the most simple lifeform, evolve to an intelligent group leader and rise to the lord af the largest empire in the entire universe. 

Mess-Around: Everything said. Build ugly monsters and use them to kill everybody, edit the surface of planets, transform water into lava, highjack your friends, wipe out innocent creatures... The only limit is your free time :D

Challengers: Who said this game was going to be easy to finish? In fact it´s impossible, the last stage is endless... And trust me, if there´s one thing you have to try to understand, it´s (Spoilers Ahead) reaching the galactic core and wiping out the Grox... I wish you fun at exterminating around 2000 star systems...

Children: I know this has a teen-rating, but seriously, nobody would be mad about a six-year old playing this. Of course you can literally take out the entire universe without showing mercy, but the brutality is way to low to be frightening to anyone... Come on, the animation isn´t even realistic...

Non-EA-haters: I am afraid, but that´s the point I have to admit. The only thing I dislike this game for, but only the Steam version. EA doesn´t let Steam-users connect to their servers, so all online-features are disables for us. Bad thing that you can´t share your creatures or download other´s epic content, but this review won´t change either. EA isn´t ready for Steam yet and won´t ever be. I think singleplayer fun can annihulate this point, but the condition is bad, that´s sure.

Do I recommend Spore to anyone else? 


I am not sure about this one, to be honest. This might be considered too kid-friendly for some adults and too boring for action-gamers. 

This review is intended to be funny, just as SPORE is. In fact I want to say that you shouldn´t miss this, SPORE is just a game everyone should at least know. Please, get it in a sale. I do not force you to play this for as long as I did. Since there are no achievements you can also get rid of this within a daytime. I am still really surprised by this, SPORE just marked the simulator-genre, it´s still the one and only god simulator. I know there aren´t even many, but those few won´t ever reach this. 

Why do I say "get it in a sale" when it seems like I am amazed enough to pay it fully?

Because I didn´t either. Spore without online support isn´t just worth it. Get the Origin version if you don´t mind. saving your progress for this is important and sharing creations keeps the community alive. SPORE is an amazing game, but the publisher isn´t a great one. 

Thanks a lot for reading until here, it means a lot to me. I'd aprechiate if you leave a rating, I care about your opinion. 

Keep it up, guys ;)

helpfulness: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Spore is an interesting, different take on the classic god-type genre of games. You begin as a single cell organsim, happily eating (plants or other organisms, or both!) and eventaully running away or fighting other organisms. As you eat, you gain DNA, which is used to modify your creature, from eyes to appendages used to attack others or defend yourself, and other some modifications that do not require DNA, such as enlarging or reducing the size and shape of your creature, enlongating or shortening your spine, even individual segments of your spine! 

After you consume enough DNA, you will be able to "find a mate" and change anything you like about your creature, including color, color patterns and layers of color and patterns, and anything else you can imagine. Really, the whole point that Spore really drives home is that your creations are only limited by your imagination. Once enough DNA and parts are gathered you can "evolve" to the next stage of evolution, in this case, evolving legs. 

Once you crawl out of the primordial soup and make landfall, you will have a nest for your species to stay in, and the real adventure begins. You will meet other species and decide if you want to befriend them through either "Impressing" them through song and dance and whatnot, or kill them into extinction. In the next stage of evolution you have a third option to send them gifts, which they may or may not accept. Each decision you make affects the outcome of your creature. Befriending tribes gives you abilities to make it easier to befriend other species in the future, as does killing them, or gifting, the economic solution. Whenever you successfully befriend, or kill a species, you will be rewarded with new parts to help evolve your creature. Many of these at this stage have actual benefits, such as arms with hands that have sharp claws, which will aid you in taking down some of the tougher species, or other parts that boost your ability to sing, dance and otherwise impress other species. As with the previous stage, once you have collected enough DNA through befriending or conquering species, you will advance to the next stage of evolution, Tribal. (NOTE: When you finish creature stage, before you advance to tribal stage you will be given one last chance to change your creature in any way you see fit. Once you enter tribal stage, NO MORE CHANGES CAN BE MADE TO YOUR CREATURE.)

The tribal stage is arguably the most difficult stage because you really have to begin managing your resources. You have to gather food to feed your tribe, and plenty extra if you plan on gifting to other tribes. You have a village and as with the previous stage, instead of parts, you have buildings in your village that will assist your tribe in your goal. At this point it is a good idea to settle on whether you plan on being a war-mongering military society, a happy-go-lucky religious society (you still sing and dance to befriend other tribes, but in the next stage you basically convert new species to your religion in order to become allies) or an economic powerhouse (in the near future, capable of purchasing entire star systems). Once you have  enough allies or conquor enough tribes, you advance to the next stage, Civilization.

Civilization stage is much like the creature stage, in that it opens up the game into a new level of depth and this time, micro-management. You will discover Spice, the source of all income, and mine the various spice gysers near and far to increase your income (which replaces DNA) and go crazy with creation. Much like your original creature, you can choose from a preset list from Maxis, or if you signed in at the beginning of the game (or at any time for that matter) you can use or modify any creation by any person who has played Spore. Of course, you can also create your own from the ground up, including a Town  Hall, a Factory, Houses, and Entertainment buildings. You can use these in city planning to create a well-balanced city. Too many factories will boost spice processing, but make your city unhappy and easily susceptible to religious attacks, which are much more effective against unhappy cities. Too many entertainment buildings will make your city happy, but your spice production will suffer. You will learn the proper balance with time, experiment and try different things, which is what Spore is all about! Anyway the objective of this stage is to destroy or ally yourself with other rival factions of your species, which has become the single most dominant sentient creature on your planet. Of course you can also establish trade routes with rival cities and eventually be given the option to purchase them, making them as much yours as a city you started with. Again, eventually you will destroy or ally yourself with all the rival factions on your planet, and advance to the final stage, Space.

This is by far and away the most fun stage in the game, and once you reach space stage with one species, you can start a new species at any stage (Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization, or Space) any time you wish. Your species has advanced enough to begin space flight! From this point, the universe is your oyster! The same ways you haved allied yourself, purchased, or conquered others until now remain the same, although, remember that at least in the beginning of space stage, your species exists on but one planet, whereas other species you meet will be spread across several planets and even start systems! If you want an accurate scope of just how huge this game is, zoom out from your planet, to your start system, complete with other planets, to your local star system cluster to eventually the entire galaxy. Every start system, every planet you see you can visit! You can establish colonies on new worlds to expand your empire, meet new species and decide how to deal with them, do missions for them, hunt for valuable artifacts, and even terraform planets from T0 (No atmosphere, very difficult to sustain a profitable colony) to a T3 oasis, with several booming colonies, ripe for the picking with all different kinds of Spice! From this point you can do whatever, go wherever, whenever you want!

All in all, if you like creative freedom, an explorative nature, and want to build your own galaxy spanning empire from a single celled organism to the most powerful species in the galaxy, this game is for you! (On a side note, Spore and Spore Creepy and Cute Parts Pack are completely compatible with Windows 8.1)

helpfulness: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: February 5
												There's a lot to be said for spore.

Tld;r Spore is a game that features multiple stages of life, each serving as a unique game-mode of sorts, all starring your own custom created lifeform, contending for survival against other randomly generated life form. The biggest flaw in this game is that each mode seems so short, and lacking depth.
If the worst thing I could say about this game is there's not enough of it, it could definitely have some worse flaws.



It's a really unique and enjoyable experience, with some glaring flaws. Its a game that allows the player to experience the evoulationary stage of their very own creations. It's greatest and worst feature is the various stages of life you play as. more on that later.
to describe the game, you start out with a cell that you modify and fight other cells. its an interesting sort of "big eat small" game type that last until you eventually evolve into the next stage of life. 
This next stage of life consists of creating a land walking creature using various parts consisting of heads, mouths, arms legs, and more, to fend for itself among a randomly generated selection of creatures, both gigantic and small. This stage is fun in its own merit, but eventually leads onto a tribal stage.
The tribal stage was the most fun for me, a sort of RTS village manager. You select groups of people to roam about the world and gather resources for the village. 
After this you evolve into a civilization style game, which wasn't bad at all either. You manage cities, their happiness and resource output and whatnot while conquering other cities. 
After this is a space exploration mode which I haven't played at this time (I know its been out forever!)

Posted: December 18, 2014
												It's fantastic being able to design and play as your own creatures.  The design possibilities are nearly limitless.  Creating and messing around briefly as your creatures is really the only great part about this game.  The Cell, Tribal, Civ, and Space stages are mostly just disappointing and tedious.  If you have a day free, you can play all the way from Cell stage to Space stage in a single sitting.  Space is agreeably the worst part of the game sense you are set as a single ship managing your entire empire. (And no expansion fixes that)  

I'm pretty upset that they gave up on this franchise.  I feel like it could have easily become amazing and complex over generations like the Sims franchise. 

TL:DR Only get this game when it's on sale.

body:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												SPORE is a very old game. It's very unique, friendly, and (against a lot of other opinions) executed very well. I remember pre-ordering the physical copy of the game as a kid. The first time I booted the game up was just mind blowing. An entire galaxy that's mine to control! I didn't care what others thought, it let my imagination run wild and showed me hundreds of hours of entertainment.
Spore is a game about imagination where the limits just keep expanding. As you progress through the game you'll be able to control a creature that you have thrown together, through the stages of evolution. Work hard to get your cell onto land. Dominate the other creatures with friendship or extinction. Take control of your tribe's continent. Unify the world's civilizations. Take control of the galaxy, one solar system at a time, and discover it's secrets. All of this can be done in a game of SPORE.
Feeling really creative? Make some friends and share your creations with eachother! To really put your creations to use, consider visiting the DLC store pages! You won't regret the extra hours and hours of gameplay, created by the community!

												I've been playing Spore pretty much since it came out, back then it was buggy as hell and unsupported, but that was ON windows Vista, and Vista sucks, I recently brought the game after I moved onto Windows 8, Spore only crashed once, literally.

Spore in my opinion is a great game, even though it's EA, but Spore is very creative and smart, starting from a very tiny fish to a full grown Galactic Space Empire, it takes a good amount of time to do the game to get to Space stage, in my opinion, Space stage is the most fun stage since I love space and exploring planets and communicating with other alien races, you can be evil like the Grox and destory alien empires, destory planets and stuff, or you can be really friendly and be friends with many alien races as possible.

My favourite easter egg in Spore is finding Earth, out of the 50,000 stars (That's how many stars there are in Spore's game), it's really hard however when you find Earth, you also find all the planets in the solar system apart from Pluto, because Pluto is not a planet anymore, fegits.

I highly recommend that you buy it, Spore is very fun.

body:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I bought the Spore Complete Pack on sale for 12.47, and I still wish I hadn't wasted the money.  I remember playing the game way back when and it was quite fun, a decent game overall.  But.... it's EA.. I should've known better to think it was really given any REAL effort.

One mistake, I'll admit, was my own.  I didn't realize that the game didn't have any autosaving, and you had to save manually.  So when the game crashed, I lost every bit of the game that I'd been playing.

Of course, the fact that having my internet go out for a few seconds caused the game to crash... I hadn't expected that to happen.   Nor did I expect to have to create an origin account for the game.   Nor did I expect to have to spend a half an hour getting it to reset my password because every time it accepted a password when I tried to login it said invalid password. ((luckily I was finally able to get a password that worked by saying something derogatory to the company in it.. they had no problem letting that go through it seems, just not a NORMAL password)).  Nor did I expect to have to reboot my entire computer just to be able to log into their servers.   

The issues are plenty, and now that I've already spent money on it, I've seen quite a few other people on the net that have had problems with it crashing.   Is the game good?   Sure, it can be fun.   But seeing as how EA infrastructure and coding can destroy just about anything.. well.. good luck if you decide to try it.   I hope you have better luck than I.

helpfulness: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												I bought this game when it was released in 2006. While Will Wright's original vision of the game was curtailed by EA's desire to rush it out, Spore has a certain charm that I love. When it came to Steam, I decided I needed to buy it again. This and the expansions are really games for people who love to create and create you can! Ships, creatures, builidings, vehicles, planets, missions, and a whole gaxaly's worth of shher fun awaits. 

It's not a "serious" space sim. You have to go into Spore with a sense of humor. It pays a loving if rather quirky tribute to Star Trek and Star Wars and other franchises - there is a HEAVY Hitchhikers CGuide to the Galaxy vibe in Spore. Now, all of that said, the base game is good, but it really shines with the Creature Cereator and goes into warp speed with GalacticAdventures. The latter expansion features on planet missions. There are both Maxis created and user created missions and they range from cute to quite frantic, violent, fast paced affairs.

I realize that Spore received mixed reviews. But bear in mind that these reviews were partly informed by the fact that Will Wright was not given time to complete his vision for this game. 

This game is a guilty pleasure for me amid all the "serious" games I play.  Spore is more of a huge creative playground and it does it better than Minecraft at least for me.

body:
Posted: 20 May, 2014
												An asteroid hurdles through space, speeding past alien spacecraft who follow it, attempting to scan it for any life. Within seconds, the asteroid is out of sight, and enters the orbit of a planet. Catching fire, it slams into the ground, creating a crater from the impact. Hundreds of small fragments explode from the asteroid, scattering themselves around the planet. Some land by cities of sophisticated, lizard-like beigns, others by curious tribes who begin worshipping the fiery rocks, and by clueless creatures who poke and lick them. One particular fragment lands in a small pool of water, and you crawl out - a small, slithery cell who's main goal is to survive. 
This is Spore, the tale of how your microscopic race can go from scavengers getting enough food to barely survive, to a thriving empire that controls the entire galaxy. The game is based on five stages: Cell, Creature, Tribe, Civilization, and Space. Cell station is where your journey begins. There is little customization in this stage, except for the basic shape of your cell and organelles. Once you become the top of the food chain, you evolve legs. Stumbling onto land, you enter the Creature Stage.
 Here is where the true customization takes place. You can collect various parts from skeletons scattered around the planet and add them to your creature. You can make a huge, strong behemoth who crushes his enemies with his gigantic claws, or a small, nimble beign that flies and steals food from his enemies before they notice he is there. You can create your creature based on your species' diet: omnivore, carnivore, or herbivore. Besides the customization, Creature Stage introduces a huge skill in the game that is incredibly useful - friends and foes. 
You can choose whether to impress other races and become friends, or attempt to destroy and annhilate them. You have to be wise as to who you attack and who you ally; making enemies with all the weak creatures could end up with them evolving into way stronger creatures and destroying YOU. Once your brain has increased, your species can begin laying out the foundations for a tribe. Here is where the friends and foes system comes into major effect. To complete the Tribal Stage and become a civilization, you must complete your Tribe Totem Pole. For every tribe you defeat or ally, a new totem is added. This stage goes by rather fast, and prepares you for Civilizational Stage. 
Civilization Stage takes inspiration from Sid Meier's Civilization series. Your goal is to control every city on the planet, whether through religious, economic, or military means. Religious races can convert the race into believing your civilization is their leader, and is considered the easiest way to complete the stage. Military is just brute force; when it comes to the guns in this, size DOES matter. Economic is peaceful; you start a trade route with a friendly city and eventually buy their city from them. This takes longer than the other two ways but can be very helpful in the long run.
Once you control the planet, you can launch a space project, starting the Space Stage, which is endless. All the choices you've made in the previous stages add up to decide what class you are in the Space Stage - perhaps a battle-crazed tyrant, or a religious zealot out to convert everyone to the teachings of Spode. During the stage, your goal is to go from the Captain of your Space Project to the Omnipotent Beign of the Universe. On the way, you'll encounter the Grox - a cyborg race who hate all and arguably are the antagonists of the game. (If hours of work are put into it, you could make them your ally- if you ever do, I commend you for your bravery.) Between space pirates, colonizing other planets, upgrading your fleet, and stabalizing your funds, this is by far my favorite stage. Overall, this is a great game for creative people and truly lets your imagination soar.

Graphics: 16/20
Story: 17/20
Gameplay: 20/20
Replayability: 19/20
Soundtrack: 18/20
Overall: 90/100

helpfulness: 38 of 60 people (63%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: March 23
												This game is too quick in terms of progression from cellular organism to space-faring creature. Once you get to space, it's the same shake-and-bake colony making: find planet suitable for life, terraform, colonize, and... do it all over again!

In other words, once you get to the "end-game" portions of the game, it ends up being very repetitive and boring. Given that EA's servers for the game are also apparently dead, and there being no Steam Workshop at the time of this writing, you don't get to share with others.

Basically, the game's missing key features now, there's no support for it, and the DLC content where your space captain goes on adventures is so clunky and buggy, I can't recommend this game anymore.

If the game is ever on sale, it might be worth picking up if you've never played it before. Don't get me wrong; the game is fun, it's just that the fun doesn't last after you've done 2 or 3 civilizations.

The verdict: this game might be worth $5 if you find yourself playing with character creation screens way too long. Otherwise, spend your hard-earned cash elsewhere.

Posted: May 3, 2016
												'SPORE' is a game where you start off crash landed from a meteor into a planet and you're trying to grow from your tiny bacteria to a large galactic nation. You play through multiple stages and choose how your civilization progresses.

Pros:

-You can play this through more then once and will get a different outcome
-You get to customize nearly EVERYTHING to your liking
-Can keep you occupied for hours
-Runs well


Cons:

-Some evoloution stages are extremly short
-Galactic stage is the longest by far and I wished the others were made longer
-No autosave so if the game DOES crash you're doomed
