												I play this game all the time and it never ever gets boring.My friends and I enjoy competeing to see who can make the most creepiest or cutest creature.
 Anyways about the game,Spore is a very fun and creative game to play.Many achevments can be unlocked and you can even set you own goals.The game is more on the lines of solo than multiplayer,but it would be cool if you could visit other people's planets and creatures.The game is basically a great game where you can create you own creatures and make them go through evolotion.
Their are alot of pros I can think of but thankfully not many cons.Here are some:
Pros:
1. Very positive
2. Entertaining
3. Creative
4. Never ends (As in their are no limits to how many creatures,planet,or games you can make.)
Cons:
1. Addicting
2. Not multiplayer (Although I'm hoping it will be in the future.)

 Well there are the pros and cons of the game Spore! I hop you found this review useful if you are interested in the game.And if you do buy it and try it,I hope you will enjoy it as much as I do!

helpfulness: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Spore is an interesting, different take on the classic god-type genre of games. You begin as a single cell organsim, happily eating (plants or other organisms, or both!) and eventaully running away or fighting other organisms. As you eat, you gain DNA, which is used to modify your creature, from eyes to appendages used to attack others or defend yourself, and other some modifications that do not require DNA, such as enlarging or reducing the size and shape of your creature, enlongating or shortening your spine, even individual segments of your spine! 

After you consume enough DNA, you will be able to "find a mate" and change anything you like about your creature, including color, color patterns and layers of color and patterns, and anything else you can imagine. Really, the whole point that Spore really drives home is that your creations are only limited by your imagination. Once enough DNA and parts are gathered you can "evolve" to the next stage of evolution, in this case, evolving legs. 

Once you crawl out of the primordial soup and make landfall, you will have a nest for your species to stay in, and the real adventure begins. You will meet other species and decide if you want to befriend them through either "Impressing" them through song and dance and whatnot, or kill them into extinction. In the next stage of evolution you have a third option to send them gifts, which they may or may not accept. Each decision you make affects the outcome of your creature. Befriending tribes gives you abilities to make it easier to befriend other species in the future, as does killing them, or gifting, the economic solution. Whenever you successfully befriend, or kill a species, you will be rewarded with new parts to help evolve your creature. Many of these at this stage have actual benefits, such as arms with hands that have sharp claws, which will aid you in taking down some of the tougher species, or other parts that boost your ability to sing, dance and otherwise impress other species. As with the previous stage, once you have collected enough DNA through befriending or conquering species, you will advance to the next stage of evolution, Tribal. (NOTE: When you finish creature stage, before you advance to tribal stage you will be given one last chance to change your creature in any way you see fit. Once you enter tribal stage, NO MORE CHANGES CAN BE MADE TO YOUR CREATURE.)

The tribal stage is arguably the most difficult stage because you really have to begin managing your resources. You have to gather food to feed your tribe, and plenty extra if you plan on gifting to other tribes. You have a village and as with the previous stage, instead of parts, you have buildings in your village that will assist your tribe in your goal. At this point it is a good idea to settle on whether you plan on being a war-mongering military society, a happy-go-lucky religious society (you still sing and dance to befriend other tribes, but in the next stage you basically convert new species to your religion in order to become allies) or an economic powerhouse (in the near future, capable of purchasing entire star systems). Once you have  enough allies or conquor enough tribes, you advance to the next stage, Civilization.

Civilization stage is much like the creature stage, in that it opens up the game into a new level of depth and this time, micro-management. You will discover Spice, the source of all income, and mine the various spice gysers near and far to increase your income (which replaces DNA) and go crazy with creation. Much like your original creature, you can choose from a preset list from Maxis, or if you signed in at the beginning of the game (or at any time for that matter) you can use or modify any creation by any person who has played Spore. Of course, you can also create your own from the ground up, including a Town  Hall, a Factory, Houses, and Entertainment buildings. You can use these in city planning to create a well-balanced city. Too many factories will boost spice processing, but make your city unhappy and easily susceptible to religious attacks, which are much more effective against unhappy cities. Too many entertainment buildings will make your city happy, but your spice production will suffer. You will learn the proper balance with time, experiment and try different things, which is what Spore is all about! Anyway the objective of this stage is to destroy or ally yourself with other rival factions of your species, which has become the single most dominant sentient creature on your planet. Of course you can also establish trade routes with rival cities and eventually be given the option to purchase them, making them as much yours as a city you started with. Again, eventually you will destroy or ally yourself with all the rival factions on your planet, and advance to the final stage, Space.

This is by far and away the most fun stage in the game, and once you reach space stage with one species, you can start a new species at any stage (Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization, or Space) any time you wish. Your species has advanced enough to begin space flight! From this point, the universe is your oyster! The same ways you haved allied yourself, purchased, or conquered others until now remain the same, although, remember that at least in the beginning of space stage, your species exists on but one planet, whereas other species you meet will be spread across several planets and even start systems! If you want an accurate scope of just how huge this game is, zoom out from your planet, to your start system, complete with other planets, to your local star system cluster to eventually the entire galaxy. Every start system, every planet you see you can visit! You can establish colonies on new worlds to expand your empire, meet new species and decide how to deal with them, do missions for them, hunt for valuable artifacts, and even terraform planets from T0 (No atmosphere, very difficult to sustain a profitable colony) to a T3 oasis, with several booming colonies, ripe for the picking with all different kinds of Spice! From this point you can do whatever, go wherever, whenever you want!

All in all, if you like creative freedom, an explorative nature, and want to build your own galaxy spanning empire from a single celled organism to the most powerful species in the galaxy, this game is for you! (On a side note, Spore and Spore Creepy and Cute Parts Pack are completely compatible with Windows 8.1)

body:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												Fantastic game that I loved back when it first came out and I love it still. 

Basically it's a mixed genre game. When you start it you have casual amoeba swimming game. Then you evolve and go to land where you go around eating fruits or other animals until you advance to tribal stage. Tribal stage becomes a kind of a lightweight RTS where you attack other tribes, create tools, equip them to your tribe members. After advancing to Civilization age, you start to build cities, defenses, vehicles (land, air, naval) and it's even more of RTS. And then you go into space... :) 

The best part of the game is definitely Creature Creator though. It's easy to use and you can make  many different cute creatures, only your imagination is the limit. Spore is a nice game, and additional pack add to the game but are optional.

You can even play with the music and change it during gameplay (different beats and stuff).

It's not the best game ever, but I can recommend it without any problems, especially if you're into building stuff (Sims, Sim City...) 

	Graphics: 	★★★★★	Sound: 	★★★★☆	Gameplay: 	★★★★☆	Music: 	★★★★☆                    	Overall: 	★★★★☆

body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												It might only say I have 0.2 hours on record, but I played this game before I even knew Steam was a thing.

Reviled at the time by many for its "Always-Online" gimmick that EA would still use for another decade afterward, Spore was a game that promised the literal "world" at its first preview showings, but did it deliver?

Honestly? No, but that's old history to most people, the game we got was, and still is, in my humble opinion however, a truly unique and creative experience that is paralleled by very few games.

The thing that makes Spore stand out, as with most Maxis games like The Sims, is its creativity. The Spore creature creator to this day is still one of the most interesting and in depth character customization mechanics in the gaming world.

Whether you want to go with some creepy, or somewhat realistic, or heck even phallic, your imagination is the limit.

Each stage of the game is based on a different stage of an organism, Single Celled, Primal, Tribal, "Civilization" (Quite literally), and Galactic.

You are going to spend the majority of your time in the Galactic phase as it is the proverbial "End-Game" to your adventure.

If I had to name any cons for the game, I'd say that each stage up to Galactic is fairly shallow, but in all honesty, this is a rather small complaint because although the game boasts having mutliple stages, it's not a "Civilazation" game, the stages are a "means to an end" so to speak.

My favorite stage is the Galactic stage, simply because once you've gotten to this point, you've kind of "grown" with your Creature race and Galactic boasts the most features of any of the stages.

The Galactic Adventures DLC essentially adds MMO-esque elements to the Galactic Stage, adding in Fetch-Quests, Escort Quests and the ability to get off on alien planets. While this is cool to break up the monotany of space trading and travel every once in awhile, even with community made quests, you are probably going to play the same 3 or 4 over, and over again.

Overall, Spore is a game that is very much remembered but often overlooked for how good it really was. 8/10.

body:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ONLINE FUNCTIONALITY, THE SERVERS ARE PERMANENTLY SHUT DOWN.

Now that I've said that, I can explain how fun HALF of this game is.

Cell stage is a sort of fun indtroductory mini-game more than a full stage. Just imagine alll those games where you eat stuff to get bigger, then eat creatures smaller than you. That's cell stage.
The Creature stage is the best part, or maybe second best part, of the game for me. I loved murdering and consuming all of my neighbours and using their limbs to find new parts to evolve. One annoyance, sometimes I couldn't tell where my species had gone when they migrated.
Tribal stage is meh. It's kinda fun at the start, until everyone else starts dominating you and you get your food stolen every ten seconds.
City stage is boring. More of the same as tribal stage, but with tanks and boats. Get through this stage as fast as possible.
Space stage is just as great as Creature stage, if not better. After being confined to one planet for so long, you finally get to build your spaceship and fly to distant star systems. Make friends with aliens, or hunt those in tribal stage for sport. It's great.

In conclusion, the first two stages of the game and the last stage are great, but Tribal and City just seem shambled together. Oh, and there's NO ONLINE FUNCTIONALITY. Screw you EA. Pick this game up when it's on sale for a fiver or so.

helpfulness: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												After finally feeling I have put in enough time to review this game I want to go a bit in depth. first let's look positive: on the plus side the cell stage made me nostalgic for the eat and row games I played as a young child. The creature stage I found thoroughly fun and enjoyable. The combat is quite simplistic and easy to navigate if your on a full red streak. Befriending creatures was fluid as well but I haven't done all that much. The user interface I found nice and friendly and had no troube navigating menus. The space stage made me feel quite free and I loved it but it definitely had its bad points.
The negatives now: the space stage was too long and I ended up choosing a planet not on looks but on what was closest to the centre, it also suffers from bad combat, a huge difficulty spike and monotony. The civ stage was too restrictive and I found boring and I won't go into the god awful village stage.

Overall I really enjoyed this game and would definitely recommend it to friends especially if it's cheap it still holds up great and you can be so so creative with it if you have the money buy it for sure.

body:
Posted: March 12
												This game was my childhood back when it was popular (Rip Spore community), it will always be my favourite game. You can play god and create your own creatures and play as them through the Cell Stage (Your creature begins its story as a cell in the water), then to Creature Stage (Your creature evolves and grows legs, moves onto the land and becomes either a killing machine or a friendly diplomatic species), to Tribal Stage (Your creature discovers fire and learns to use tools, and thus begins the Tribal Stage where you have to either fight or befriend other tribes to evolve), to Civilization Stage (Your creature's species evolves to the Civilization Stage which is pretty much modern today, much like tribal stage, you must either befriend or destroy every other Civilization on the planet to evolve, but this time you will have a Navy, Airforce, ect), and finally the Space Stage (Yourr creature's species evolves into the Space Stage, the most complicated stage but in my opinion the most enjoyable stage in the game, you have the ENTIRE Galaxy to explore with over 100 other alien Empires to either go to war with, or befriend and trade with. But then once you approach the center of the Galaxy, you encounter an Empire so vicious and deadly they could simply conqure the entire Galaxy with ease if they wanted to, so beware...). The DLC for this game add amazing new content that will improve your game, Galactic Adventures is the best one though ;). On steam i have about 3 hours of playtime with Spore, but at the time i had the game and DLC on disc, and i eventually got them on steam when i recently lost my spore game cases.


Rip Maxis

body:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Spore is a great game. I've been playing for over 24 hours now in total across Spore and Spore: Galactic Adventures. You start off as a cell, evolve into higher level species and eventually become a spacefaring civilization. I've learned a few different things about the game that I feel newer players could have use of knowing.

Evolve your creature to max in the creature stage if you plan on playing with Galactic Adventures. You will be using creature stage abilities a lot here, better make sure that it becomes as easy as possible for you.
Save often. Spore crashes occasionally, and with the immersiveness of the game, it's easy to forget to save. Spore does NOT have auto-save functionality.
One more thing that a lot of people miss: BACK UP YOUR SPORE DATA FOLDERS! I had the game suddenly delete all my progress in Spore without any warning. I don't know the programming logic that would result in such a thing happening, but when I launched Spore yesterday, I was greeted with the main menu with no saves in it. Luckily I already had an older backup of the data as I copied it for playing on another computer once, but I've lost a lot of progress.
Spore data folders may be found at %appdata%\Spore as well as "My Spore Creatures" in your Documents folder. Back them up regularly.

body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Purchased on disc back at launch. Repurchased on Steam a while back. All my creations are still cloud saved, and can reuse my old designs from 8 years ago. A+. 10/10

As for gameplay, I have broken it down to each stage below:

Cell stage is fun, Pac-man-esque without the wall barriers, fun, simple, neat.

Creature stage is okay, slightly tedious if your are the sort of player that needs EVERY type of body part before continuing. 

Tribe stage is very much a one-trick wonder. Don’t over think it, complete quickly, move on.

City stage is kinda fun, building cities quickly becomes a copy paste exercise, but tearing down the cities of your enemies through commerce, religion or focer is all equally satisfying!

Space stage is the pinnacle of the game, you start with very little, you must work and manage trade routes, and blasting cities apart on neighbouring system to progress. Money starts tight, and pew-pew sounds easier; but allies do help early-mid game. Micro managing planetary spice is annoying to set up, but satisfying  when the wonga rolls in. Ecological disasters and space pirate raiding keeps you from rushing away from home too quickly. The balance is  good between feeling far too easy, and flipping around to a point where a new disaster happens every few minutes. 

I haven’t got to the end yet. This is definitely a game worth the £15 price tag, from a person who paid full brick and mortar retail at launch. If it’s on sale, snap it up.

body:
Posted: March 23
												I wish the game was longer or more complex. Or harder. I'd really love it if you could only make a few changes at any time. Being able to completely change your monster EVERY. SINGLE. TIME is AWFUL.

It's a fun game, but it really needs to be taken to a higher level to be what it should have been.

I'd be willing to buy into a hard-choices, slow-develepment, restrictive version of this game. By all means, tie-in a creature builder...I don't care about that, but I want the development of my species to be HARD AND PAINFUL.

Pros: 

Easy to use
Easy to pick up
Easy to win.
Allows for maximum creativeity at any point in your development

Cons:

So easy that it's got very little replayability, which is nonsense.
No natural flow of development - you can delete your character and just make a new one every time you breed.
no restrictions that make it FEEL like you're evolving a creature or their culture
No 'hard mode'.

Conclusion:

Better for kids with no patience. Anyone with the remotest amount of patience can DESTROY this game without effort.

body:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												IF YOU HAVE PROBLEMS RUNNING SPORE:

Go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore" and find the file called "runme.exe". Right click it and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP SP2.
Now go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore\SporeBin" and find "SporeApp.exe" - do the same, set the compatibility mode to WinXP SP2.

This should now work. I didn't have to do anything on my Windows 10 x64 machine, but I had to do this for my gf's Win8 machine because nothing else would work.

Hope this helps!

Otherwise - the game is very fun :)

body:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Spore is a bit incredulously ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

It introduces something amazing, an entirely new concept with you, but when you get about halfway through the game it takes that all away from you with hardly any reason or meaning why.

Playing a new game, you start as a little microbe thing with some very basic gameplay and some addictive mechanics. The goal of this stage is to eat and get bigger until you fill up the meter at the bottom, it's promising but gets boring fast which is just as well because the stage can be over that fast if you want it to be and you can move on to become a proper Spore creature, going into Creature stage.

Creature stage... is the best part of the game. This is the part where you're shown an almost infinite variety and customizability combinations in the creature editor, with all sorts of interesting options and different things. You can make a four or six legged monstrosity with ♥♥♥♥ing spikeballs coming out of it's nose or maybe a ball with a pair of legs and four arms, with a ridiculous variety of hands, mouths, eyes, assortments of weapons and the likes.

And if that didn't already appeal to you, on top of all this, you're shown an expansive world with other species which you can befriend or extinct and giant ♥♥♥♥ing creatures you can attempt to slay if you get powerful enough for thrills. And this courses through an ENTIRE PLANET of these other species and massive creatures. This appealed to me so much that I absolutely loved everything about it, it was so thrilling, it was absolutely majestic and wonderful.

But then comes Tribal stage. Once you're filled on the meter at the bottom and maybe have the full look for your creature that you want, the content was pretty stunted there. Personally, I would have loved to have the whole game be Creature stage, just getting progressively better.

Instead, it's all taken away from you. You're shown an entirely different genre of game in some sadistic attempt to radically change your idea on playing the game. Initially, I dismissed this as EA's standard policy to alienate their entire ♥♥♥♥ing demographic and tried to make sense of it, but no.

Your love that you put into your creature to maybe make it more socially friendly or combat advantageous in Creature stage? Poof. The only things you retain from Creature stage are the actual planet (which is no longer free-roam), the other species on it (now lowered to domestic pets and other rising tribes which are pretty generic and bland) and the look of your creature as well as it's voice and how it moves (like if you have a four-legged creature, it moves the same way it did when you were controlling it yourself, but it's generic and loses it's charm). The whole game turned into this forced, linear pathway that is completely different from what was shown to you earlier.

Tribal was pretty short, though. Civilisation stage... Ugh. It introduced an entirely new editor, but it was like it was trying to shoehorn user creativity back into the game, but with no real purpose. The things in Creature stage were actually relevant to the gameplay, like combat and social, with the other idea of it being whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want and it can apply to the actual gameplay, like moving on. While Civilisation stage things do have the element of application to gameplay, it's just less and less content. There's only the coolness in making vehicles. That's it.

Space stage is another step where the Civilisation stage was going in the first place, you deal in planets instead of nations/cities, you deal with a galaxy instead of a world... It's incredibly boring, though. There's combat segments and some customization, but the game lost all charm for me at this point.


But yes, if you agree with everything I said and want to buy the game, then NEVER progress past Creature stage unless you REALLY want to. It's not that rewarding. Incredible beginning content with incredible mechanics, but really sucks later on.

body:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												Spore is a great game with a ton of unique features that make this game differnt from the others. After playing it again and again i can say that this is a game with much replay value allowing players to experiment with differnt combinations of creature types like becoming an omnivore or becoming a waring civilization or simply making it so your species can finnacially succeed. I can also say that all the different stages add something different to the emersion of gameplay whether your managing food in tribal or designing new vehicles in the civilazation stage.The space stage may seem repetitve and tedious but not only does the rest of the game make up for it but the creators added the Galactic Adventures DLC to make things more interesting. But, as an older games there is expected to be bugs to it graphically or bugs that affect gameplay. The only major one i've come across with my crappy computer was an occasinally crash that shuts the program out. A simple solution is to simply save the game constantly. Besides that there is hours of gameplay that is fun to pick up once and a while. I suggest this to anyone who just wants to play god and screw with life. Even though it says i have only played it for a small amount of time i've been playing it on a seperate file on the DLC for over a hundred hours so listen to some of my advice.

body:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Since I've played a little bit, let me tell you why it's awesome:
 In General The game has multiple stages: Cell stage, Creature Stage, Tribal Stage, Civilization Stage, and Space stage.
 You can make friends and enemies
 YOU CAN KILL EVERYONE
 You can befriend everyone <3 (at least until you get into the civ stage, where everyone hates you)
 The video above this review makes this game look nothing like it actually is.
 3 Different levels of difficulties: Easy, Normal, and Hard. 
 Cell stage  EAT  EVERYTHING  AS AN OMNIVORE. EVERYTHIIING!!!! 
*OR*
 Eat just plants as an herbivore.
 Eat just meat as a carnivore
 What you decide to eat is what you eat for the rest of the game. You can also put on herbivore and carnivore mouths on to eat things other than what you mostly ate in the cell stage
 BECOME THE MOST MONSTROUS SPERM CELL TO EVER EXIST
 Eat things for DNA points.
 Creature Stage  ♥♥♥♥♥ monsters.
 You can literally make almost anything you want.
 Kill things or socialize with things for dna points to customize your creature.
 Tribal Stage SPOILER  IF YOU PLAY THIS ON A CARNIVORE RUN ON HARD, PREPARE YOUR ♥♥♥♥ FOR A LONG GAME OF WAR
 Food is the new DNA. Run out of food and you're screwed.  I'm almost certain that being an herbivore is easier
 Kill people and destroy their tribes to add to your totem pole
 Befriend people and add them to your totem pole
 Hate everyone because they are ALWAYS ♥♥♥♥ING ATTACKING YOU

 Civilization Stage  Laugh at everyone when you destroy or take over their cities
 Laugh at everyone who accepts your cheap buy offers
 Hate every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ military city
 Place building in your cities in any way you want to. 
 Space Stage  Have no idea what you are doing
 Find out what to do
 Become the second largest empire in the galaxy
 Have more money than you know what to do with
 Kill everyone
 Befriend everyone
Thats about all I have to say about this game. Enjoy!

Serious review under here.
I used to play this game all the time on a friend's computer. It was my favourite game.
The Summer Steam Sale comes along and I found this gem again.
There is so much stuff to do, it's awesome.
The graphics are okay until you make your own creatures and plants. Then they will pop everywhere and you will have forests of poorly made plants (I'm not saying you can't make good stuff. But you will mostly mess around, and you will be surrounded by your mistakes).
Controls are kinda confusing for me.
But the concept and gameplay is so worth it.

body:
Posted: March 8
												Update! Got Spore to work with Steam now. So ignore hours played here. I've well over 600+ hours with this game since it's release quite some time ago.

So Spore is a God game of sorts, which would be ironic considering it focuses mostly on evolution for what should be the meat of the game. Depending on how you play however, it can still be a good chunk. Starting off from a tiny organism in the primordial soup, you work your way up through the food chain by consuming matter and gaining points to evolve new parts to make you more dangerous, defensive or the alpha being in the micro world. Eventually you gain the ability to have the very basic instincts of a sentient creature, growing legs and walking onto land where you proceed to evolve as before in a much larger world. From there you eventually gain a higher thought process and begin displaying the ability to form a cohesive society capable of thinking. From there you move through what's something of a crude cross between an RTS and several janky game mechanics to befriend or defeat other tribes which appear in the world. Eventually moving on to be the dominant species and begin warring with other nations which spring up. You've several ways to dominate the planet, truth be told, the mechanics behind conquering the world are the same for any path really.

And then onto the true meat of the game. Space exploration, terraforming new worlds, meeting new space empires and either kill, conquer or buy worlds from them. And then, the steam for this game begins to die down and the fun train slows substantially. Sure, at first exploring the stars is fun, but after awhile it can begin to become more of a chore to hop around space, meeting certain goals and milestones to improve your ship and empire and defending against aggressive or downright hostile space beings. I will say though, it took a long time, but your ultimate goal is to reach the center of the galaxy. I won't say what you find of course, so the truly curious will have to find their way there or just look it up online like a panzy.

Now as for the different stages of evolving a creature, a bit more in depth.

Just to note, as you progress through the stages you can choose different paths such as herbivore and carnivore which then translate into other catagories later in the game such as industrious, warlord or peaceful. All of which give some special abilities in the tribal, civilization and space stages and also effect how your creatures evolve in what parts are available in evolution.

The first two stages, cell and creature, are fairly similar in mechanics in terms of gaining DNA to evolve. The cell stage is very simple, depending on your difficulty, but typically isn't hard to get through at all. Then the creature stage which uses the same mechanics of the cell stage, but on land and much more three dimensional. The game is a bit silly in how to befriend other creatures, using silly but amusing mechanics. Combat is essentially two animals clawing at each other until one or the other is dead. This is where you begin really planning your creatures evolution a bit more. You can shape it's torso, head and any other appendage to your liking, making everything from humanoid bipedal creatures or a giant ♥♥♥♥♥ hopping around. Whatever floats your boat or finds your lost remote, weirdo.

When it comes to interacting with the world, whether it's combat or communication, it functions quite a bit like an MMO actually. You click where you want to go or use the typical WSAD keys to move around. Hotkeys, 1234 and such will perform actions depending on what you're doing with small cooldown timers. When moving on after you've gotten enough DNA, the camera mechanics and interactions perform roughly the same for the Tribal stage. This is probably the shortest stage there is. You can easily and quickly defeat or befriend other tribes and chances are it'll take about thirty or forty minutes. Operates the same with hotkeys and movement, but more like a badly formed RTS where you can move units around to collect resources and the such.

Next is the Civilization stage which is pretty bland to tell the truth. You can design your own land, water and air vehicles in just about whatever fashion you see fit. In terms of conquering, they're all pretty much the same except for trade which allows you to peacefully buy other civilizations land, but to some extent works on the same mechanics. Then you get to the true meat of the game. SPACE. And at first it's pretty amazing with how massive of a galaxy you have to explore. You'll meet a handful of different species near you, explore different planets and stars that you've seen in the sky since you first crawled onto land.

Terraforming, now there's a thing. At first it's pretty neat, slowly shaping a world to sustain life, plopping plants and animals to create a stable ecosystem so you can build colonies to populate new worlds. Along with colonizing you can collect a substance found on many planets called Spice. In this time, the most precious substance in the universe is the spice. The spice extends life. The spice expands conciousness. The spice is vital to space travel. Actually, no it's just a valuable trading commodity of different colors and rarity. You can trade spices between different systems and eventually, in most cases, be able to buy the system and aquire new planets to claim as your own.

Now things start to sort of fall apart when it comes to advancing. For a bit all these things are a bit of fun and in short bursts, it can be. However after awhile the game becomes tedious and more of a task. The expansion for the game, Galactic Adventures, does add a fairly decent amount to do, but comes across as excessively cheesy and hokey, though I imagine the target audience was a bit younger than most of the people actually playing the game or somebody at Maxis and/or EA was smoking the dank and watching far to many kids shows on Saturday morning. But a fair amount, if not almost half of other missions aren't so bad and involve a combat system which reflects what you would have experience back in the creature stage. Just with lasers and such. It does make for a less tedious but slower method to obtain Sporebucks, though you eventually reach the point where expanding your civilization, which requires massive amounts of Sporebucks to upgrade your ship. Keep it up though and this grind isn't to bad, but then you're left with even less goals to pursue as you look forward to the tedious journey to the center of the galaxy.

Oh right, your ship. Almost forgot. So you get to design a space ship of any design at the beginning of the Space stage. It doesn't matter what parts you put on it, as your ships abilities, defences and other functions are unlocked in other ways. So the design is purely aesthetic. Controls are the WSAD setup with your cursor acting as a point of aiming. Combat is usually fairly simple and becomes somewhat routine after awhile. Once you upgrade your ship enough though, combat becomes hardly a challenge and becomes more of a management thing in simply making sure your ship stays fueled and powered up.

There's not much else to say here. I will note, I remember this game being hyped up beyond belief and being a great letdown to a lot of people. I didn't feel all that disapointed, but felt there was a much greater goal this game could have accomplished rather than slowly fizzling out in its gameplay late game. I'm sure some people find the tasks entertaining for a long time, but I've found it's better in short bursts in the late game, as just about everything else can be done in a matter of six to ten hours.

So is this game with the expansions worth $40(USD)? That's a shaky yes. But if you're not willing, wait for a sale. With that, I am about to hit the maximum amount of characters available to write a rev--

body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												As long as you're not expecting a very serious game, this game is great.   It has a variety of modes/stages to play in, starting as a basic Cell, evolving through an early creature stage through to a large space-faring species, with the fate of the galaxy in your, seemingly the only capable hands in the entire galaxy.  It is very light-hearted sort of story, even the biggest villains in the universe aren't that bad, and the game itself doesn't take itself very seriously.  The Creators are pretty robust if you have a good imagination, you could create an entire species that looks like Bart Simpson, or ships that look like giant butterflies, very close to anything you want.

body:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												This game is impeccable. The space stage is very fun, and it is a sandbox, which i really like. Although once you are Omnipotent, there is not much else you can do other than go to war, ally with other aliens and spread your colony throughout the galaxy. I played the space age for about 48 hours before i got a bit bored, and right now i am allying with the big bad meanie beanie who are the grox. I have always been looking for a game in which you evolve, but not an extremely serious one, this has multiple fun stages for you to enjoy, and many achievements for you to collect. The cell stage is like agar.io and one of the LEAST fun ones because it is so short (I can do it in 5 minutes without a particular rush) and then you grow legulars and go onto the creature stage (the least fun in my opinion, but for many it is a favourite. Tribal stage, oh tribal stage. I find it very fun! I just go around befriending other tribes :) Civilisation stage is one of the funnest. I like being religious and converting everyone :3 then space!! It actually does have a main goal and that is to go to the centre of the galaxy, which i found quite a challenge but when i did it it was so worth it for you get a very useful tool :3 10/10 would evolve again.

body:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												Ok, I've been playing this game since I was.. I... I can't remember. I just cannot say enough good things about this game. I've spent more time than is reasonable, and was rather obsesseded actually. I DO however, remember being devoured by giant monstrosities, befriending others, and conquering the universe.
  "Ok, gotta put those eyes over there.. Maybe this should be a Cyclops! No.. Perhaps a tail hat! Definitely a mustache, oh yes. And a nose ring." Just one of the many things I remember thinking.
  This game is truly huge. It has so many aspects, that I've replayed it more times than I can count and am still thoroughly enjoying myself. If you have even the faintest creative spark in you, this game is for you.
  Please Note: This was released in 2008. It's not going to have the best graphics, or anything like that. It just makes it even more impressive that this kind of game was developed and released that long ago.

body:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												It only took me 8 years to play it... yes, get it. You can feel the quality, it's a powerful game, every phase is new and well done and the progression feels great. It might feel short after the first playthrough though.
I have no idea if the online features work and I don't really care. There are minor bugs and problems with the AI, for example in tribal stage when gathering food, but playing around with your own creations makes more than up for it. 
For example: you may see your ship from the other playthrough abducting other creatures or crashed in some random planet... The end game, in space, it's an almost endless sandbox to play in. I like it, every game should have this.

tl;dr Great replay value, great game, complex but inviting.

body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												This game was awesome right when I started playing it. You start out as a little cell and the gameplay it much like agario in this stage.Then you evolve and grow legs so you can walk the earth in this stage you can either find Parts by roaming the world of extincting a species or allying with them.There is three different ways you can go.You can either be a Herbivore,Omnivore,or a carnivore.The way you pick will effect you for the rest of the game because it gives you special abilitias depending on what you are.Then there is the tribal stage, The tribal stage is where you command you tribe to go and destroy or ally with another village, Either way you pick it will give you either new tools,weapons,or instruments.Then there is the civilization stage where you get to make tanks,ships,and airships. Then either capture,destroy,or ally with all the other cities, you can also send tanks and ships to collect spice. Then there is my personal favorite stage the space stage.In the space stage you upgrade you ship,go through the galaxy allying,fighting, or capturing entire colonies and planets.There is also a species called the Grog that do not trust people.You can also have more than one world.

helpfulness: 47 of 83 people (57%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Did not live up to its hype.

Would be a fine and fun sandbox game, however, if EA's idea of "game help" wasn't "sure, we know as a new Origin user you can't access online features. We know this is a major part of the game you just paid for. We have had an "unresolved" on this issue up on our "help" page since July. We're aware. We just don't care. In fact, we're shutting down the online servers next year anyhow, so why even bother?"

If you did not have an Origin account before June 2013, be aware you will not be able to access patches or online features. Otherwise, it's not a bad game, if a little restrictive.

https://help.ea.com/article/spore-login-issue-for-new-origin-customers

Please also see comments below. I had edited that into this review on the 19th Dec but apparently the info didn't save.

helpfulness: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Spore is an interesting, different take on the classic god-type genre of games. You begin as a single cell organsim, happily eating (plants or other organisms, or both!) and eventaully running away or fighting other organisms. As you eat, you gain DNA, which is used to modify your creature, from eyes to appendages used to attack others or defend yourself, and other some modifications that do not require DNA, such as enlarging or reducing the size and shape of your creature, enlongating or shortening your spine, even individual segments of your spine! 

After you consume enough DNA, you will be able to "find a mate" and change anything you like about your creature, including color, color patterns and layers of color and patterns, and anything else you can imagine. Really, the whole point that Spore really drives home is that your creations are only limited by your imagination. Once enough DNA and parts are gathered you can "evolve" to the next stage of evolution, in this case, evolving legs. 

Once you crawl out of the primordial soup and make landfall, you will have a nest for your species to stay in, and the real adventure begins. You will meet other species and decide if you want to befriend them through either "Impressing" them through song and dance and whatnot, or kill them into extinction. In the next stage of evolution you have a third option to send them gifts, which they may or may not accept. Each decision you make affects the outcome of your creature. Befriending tribes gives you abilities to make it easier to befriend other species in the future, as does killing them, or gifting, the economic solution. Whenever you successfully befriend, or kill a species, you will be rewarded with new parts to help evolve your creature. Many of these at this stage have actual benefits, such as arms with hands that have sharp claws, which will aid you in taking down some of the tougher species, or other parts that boost your ability to sing, dance and otherwise impress other species. As with the previous stage, once you have collected enough DNA through befriending or conquering species, you will advance to the next stage of evolution, Tribal. (NOTE: When you finish creature stage, before you advance to tribal stage you will be given one last chance to change your creature in any way you see fit. Once you enter tribal stage, NO MORE CHANGES CAN BE MADE TO YOUR CREATURE.)

The tribal stage is arguably the most difficult stage because you really have to begin managing your resources. You have to gather food to feed your tribe, and plenty extra if you plan on gifting to other tribes. You have a village and as with the previous stage, instead of parts, you have buildings in your village that will assist your tribe in your goal. At this point it is a good idea to settle on whether you plan on being a war-mongering military society, a happy-go-lucky religious society (you still sing and dance to befriend other tribes, but in the next stage you basically convert new species to your religion in order to become allies) or an economic powerhouse (in the near future, capable of purchasing entire star systems). Once you have  enough allies or conquor enough tribes, you advance to the next stage, Civilization.

Civilization stage is much like the creature stage, in that it opens up the game into a new level of depth and this time, micro-management. You will discover Spice, the source of all income, and mine the various spice gysers near and far to increase your income (which replaces DNA) and go crazy with creation. Much like your original creature, you can choose from a preset list from Maxis, or if you signed in at the beginning of the game (or at any time for that matter) you can use or modify any creation by any person who has played Spore. Of course, you can also create your own from the ground up, including a Town  Hall, a Factory, Houses, and Entertainment buildings. You can use these in city planning to create a well-balanced city. Too many factories will boost spice processing, but make your city unhappy and easily susceptible to religious attacks, which are much more effective against unhappy cities. Too many entertainment buildings will make your city happy, but your spice production will suffer. You will learn the proper balance with time, experiment and try different things, which is what Spore is all about! Anyway the objective of this stage is to destroy or ally yourself with other rival factions of your species, which has become the single most dominant sentient creature on your planet. Of course you can also establish trade routes with rival cities and eventually be given the option to purchase them, making them as much yours as a city you started with. Again, eventually you will destroy or ally yourself with all the rival factions on your planet, and advance to the final stage, Space.

This is by far and away the most fun stage in the game, and once you reach space stage with one species, you can start a new species at any stage (Cell, Creature, Tribal, Civilization, or Space) any time you wish. Your species has advanced enough to begin space flight! From this point, the universe is your oyster! The same ways you haved allied yourself, purchased, or conquered others until now remain the same, although, remember that at least in the beginning of space stage, your species exists on but one planet, whereas other species you meet will be spread across several planets and even start systems! If you want an accurate scope of just how huge this game is, zoom out from your planet, to your start system, complete with other planets, to your local star system cluster to eventually the entire galaxy. Every start system, every planet you see you can visit! You can establish colonies on new worlds to expand your empire, meet new species and decide how to deal with them, do missions for them, hunt for valuable artifacts, and even terraform planets from T0 (No atmosphere, very difficult to sustain a profitable colony) to a T3 oasis, with several booming colonies, ripe for the picking with all different kinds of Spice! From this point you can do whatever, go wherever, whenever you want!

All in all, if you like creative freedom, an explorative nature, and want to build your own galaxy spanning empire from a single celled organism to the most powerful species in the galaxy, this game is for you! (On a side note, Spore and Spore Creepy and Cute Parts Pack are completely compatible with Windows 8.1)

body:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												Ive known about this game before it came out when i was younger, And i still love the hell out of it today. Hands down one of my favorite games, But this little gem has its flaws and its perfections.

Spore, i can easily say is one of those games which you can let your imagination run wild, make whatever you like, And isnt too complex. So its easy to pick up and learn. Plus the main game, besides the Creature/Building/Vehicle creator, Is pretty fun too; evolving from a simple cell, into a complex creature, then into a tribe, into a nation, and lastly, into a vast empire in space. The replay value of this game can be high, Depends how much you liked the game.

Now as for its flaws... The game has its bug, sure all games have their bugs. But Spore has had some unusual ones. Before i had the game on steam, I owned up to three copies of spore. All stopped working after some time. Each one having a strange error prior to just dying, The last copy i had affected Space Stage, Every Empire, Planet, Solar System, and Galactic Formation were all named 'BADDATA'. Now does this affect the steam version of Spore? I dunno, hasnt happened yet and i dont see anyone else complaining about it. As for some problems that i see with Spore on steam; The game does crash often, and with almost all games that crash often, The game isnt good with autosaves, And if im correct only saves once you get to the next stage. So this can easily set you really far back in Space stage, Sometimes making it not too fun to play. Plus there is the price. The game is kinda dated, and has some problems, So it isnt worth the $20.

So if its on sale, Go buy this game, im sure it will be an experience.
Now if its not on sale, Get something that you may want instead, unless you really want Spore. then get Spore.

helpfulness: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR ONLINE FUNCTIONALITY, THE SERVERS ARE PERMANENTLY SHUT DOWN.

Now that I've said that, I can explain how fun HALF of this game is.

Cell stage is a sort of fun indtroductory mini-game more than a full stage. Just imagine alll those games where you eat stuff to get bigger, then eat creatures smaller than you. That's cell stage.
The Creature stage is the best part, or maybe second best part, of the game for me. I loved murdering and consuming all of my neighbours and using their limbs to find new parts to evolve. One annoyance, sometimes I couldn't tell where my species had gone when they migrated.
Tribal stage is meh. It's kinda fun at the start, until everyone else starts dominating you and you get your food stolen every ten seconds.
City stage is boring. More of the same as tribal stage, but with tanks and boats. Get through this stage as fast as possible.
Space stage is just as great as Creature stage, if not better. After being confined to one planet for so long, you finally get to build your spaceship and fly to distant star systems. Make friends with aliens, or hunt those in tribal stage for sport. It's great.

In conclusion, the first two stages of the game and the last stage are great, but Tribal and City just seem shambled together. Oh, and there's NO ONLINE FUNCTIONALITY. Screw you EA. Pick this game up when it's on sale for a fiver or so.

body:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												Okay....soo I am reviewing this from when I played it many years ago shortly after it came out on PC. At the time I remember looking this game up and seeing its promise for a in-depth evolution system which seemed almost too complicated for me to understand but sure looked fun as hell~

So I got it on a CD at some point and I remember playing it all night and day. It was a few weeks before I stopped but while playing it I felt like it was missing something, like I was playing half of the game that was promised. At the time I was on end-game stuff which is the spaceship stage (which pretty much never ends). So I started to realize it isn't really complicated and in-depth as it was promised to be. It seems more basic and nothing super advanced.... but I still loved it. Its a shame though because it could of still been something much MUCH bigger if it had more depth. Also apparently some of the Sport EA servers are shut down now so there isn't much of a community for the game now.

To keep it short...the game is really fun if you like a mixture of RPG, Sims, Strategy games with heavy customization to keep it personal and unique to every person. I highly recommend this game still even if it is a bit dull around the edges.

body:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I played this game about 30 hours (on the c&c dlc which is counted as stand-alone game on steam), and a bunch more a few years back, but I feel there could be much more to do: if you get deep into the game it will gift you with at least 40-50 hours of gameplay imho.

Though the First stages might seem the most original and appealing, you may find out instead the space one isn't odd/dull at all. Once you get used to the sci-fi-like RTS aspects of the 2 last levels you'll realise how fun it is to expand your terrestrial empire first and your cosmic one later on.

So to sum up I really loved manipulating the genes to form powerful cells or creatures, and I liked badly to customise my vehicles, citisens and structures (the game really lets you use your skills in architecture and design); but the space stage isn't to be understimated - I promise myself I'll get back to it sometimes as it's the one I played the least.

body:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!

- Serves 4
- 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook
- 325 calories / serving
- Healthy

INGREDIENTS:

- 1 orange, zested and juiced
- 2tbsp soy sauce
- 2tbsp sesame oil
- 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli
- 5cm (2in) piece root ginger
- 1tbsp sunflower oil
- 1 garlic clove, finely sliced
- 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced
- 150g Straight To Wok Noodles
- 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices

METHOD

Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.

Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.

Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.

Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.

Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

body:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												At first I was going to get this game just to say that No Man's Sky is the off brand version of this. But as I started to play the game I then realized of how much of a great game this is. In Spore you get to progress froma a simple unicellular organism and gradually progress to the early stages of the human and eventually surpasing the human technology is the space stage of the game. You get to extend your creativity considering that you have the potential to create and evolve your creature, and later even design your own vehicles and buildings. This has many different games inside of it: cell stage being like a more graphically instive version of agar.io (Btw I never knew that it looks like agar.io took there idea from spore), the survival aspect of the land stage, the real time strategy aspects of both the tribal and civilization stage, and finally the unlimited diplomatic and warring space stage. Incredible game.

												This game is impeccable. The space stage is very fun, and it is a sandbox, which i really like. Although once you are Omnipotent, there is not much else you can do other than go to war, ally with other aliens and spread your colony throughout the galaxy. I played the space age for about 48 hours before i got a bit bored, and right now i am allying with the big bad meanie beanie who are the grox. I have always been looking for a game in which you evolve, but not an extremely serious one, this has multiple fun stages for you to enjoy, and many achievements for you to collect. The cell stage is like agar.io and one of the LEAST fun ones because it is so short (I can do it in 5 minutes without a particular rush) and then you grow legulars and go onto the creature stage (the least fun in my opinion, but for many it is a favourite. Tribal stage, oh tribal stage. I find it very fun! I just go around befriending other tribes :) Civilisation stage is one of the funnest. I like being religious and converting everyone :3 then space!! It actually does have a main goal and that is to go to the centre of the galaxy, which i found quite a challenge but when i did it it was so worth it for you get a very useful tool :3 10/10 would evolve again.

body:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												If you're gonna get it, get it while it's 5 bucks. That is the price it is really worth, maybe 6. This game is a good stepping-stone for the evolution genre, and a few other indie games are following in it's path if you dig around on the internet. It's the first iteration of a still new genre. You can create a variety of your own creatures in the brilliant creature creator, and the main appeal of this is being able to see other people's creations in your world! Cool right?

Well EA has abandoned this game, so don't expect to see anything cool other than what the game developers put in there. Sometimes you can see your own creations, so that's cool.

Unfortunately, despite the variety of creatures, most of them behave the same way. You a few abilities, ranging from stealth to very limited flying. You can be a herbivore, omnivore, or carnivore.

The game has 5 stages that are all pretty different, but the game shines in Creature mode, the second stage. Where you control one creature in your species, and evolve it as it gets more sentient. Like I said before, most creatures behave the same way in Creature mode. They all hang around in their nests and hardly interact with eachother, and if they do they don't do it enough. I wanted to see creatures huntings other creatures, and bird-like creatures and bugs, but all I saw was one wandering into an aggressive territory and getting slaughtered. There is no variety of roles in the ecosystem of the game. It's just "Five Boogleborfs hanging around a nest. Kill them or sing at them?" And that's it.

 Sometimes you see "Epics" which are huge creatures, that are indeed epic. Every once in a while a world event happens, like a meteor shower or a UFO flies by. While cool, they don't mean anything.

They did a good job of making a world that looks real from far away. But get closer, and you see all sorts of flaws and places for massive improvement.

Buy it now while it's 5 bucks. Otherwise I don't recommend. Stick around, in a while "THRIVE" will come out. Look it up, it sounds good.

EDIT: It's good for kids though. I got this game when I was a little naive to the world of gaming, that's where most of my playtime come from.

body:
Posted: March 23
												I actually like this game quite a bit, honestly, though mostly for Nostalgia reasons and the Creature Builder specifically

Good Parts
- you can make aliens of your own design and casually Play God

- It's pretty cute - the graphics aren't super realistic and thus haven't suffered too bad with aging, at least aesthetically

- This might just be a personal thing bcs I'm a sucker for worldbuilding/storywriting but it's fun to sort of evolve your little alien dude(s) into an empire and like,,, make up their history based on what happens

- This game is actually moddable, though be warned bcs it involves dropping files Directly into the game's data folder and you can't share creations made with modded parts

- It's also kinda fun to just poke around w/ the data sometimes and mess around w/ the Startup Conditions to unlock Hidden Developer Creators (the Flora and Cell Editors, for example)

Bad Parts
- It gets really, really repetitive after a while

- A lot of people (myself included) have a hard time getting the graphics to actually 'function' and register that you've set them on 'High' - I suspect this is because this game is from like just before the 2010's so it might not know how to run on modern hardware. There's a mod/fix for this somwhere if you go googling but i haven't gotten it to work

- There's quite a few bugs but *most* of the major game breaking ones have been fixed for ages.

- I have no idea if the Steam version of this has the DRM that it started with - if it does this is a Very Bad Part

- The online function is ♥♥♥♥ed on the Steam version - you have to register the game with Origin to get it to go online (though fortunately you do NOT have to buy it again - just register the CD key into it and you're good. You also don't have to bother w/ Origin after this and can never touch it again)


Despite the negatives outweighing the positives, I'm still gonna mark this as Recommended as it's a pretty fun game I feel.
EDIT TO ADD I'd still wait for it to be on sale to buy it - it's an Alright game but $20 USD for the base game + the DLC is quite a lot and when it's on sale it averages to $15 USD for all three items.

helpfulness: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												It might only say I have 0.2 hours on record, but I played this game before I even knew Steam was a thing.

Reviled at the time by many for its "Always-Online" gimmick that EA would still use for another decade afterward, Spore was a game that promised the literal "world" at its first preview showings, but did it deliver?

Honestly? No, but that's old history to most people, the game we got was, and still is, in my humble opinion however, a truly unique and creative experience that is paralleled by very few games.

The thing that makes Spore stand out, as with most Maxis games like The Sims, is its creativity. The Spore creature creator to this day is still one of the most interesting and in depth character customization mechanics in the gaming world.

Whether you want to go with some creepy, or somewhat realistic, or heck even phallic, your imagination is the limit.

Each stage of the game is based on a different stage of an organism, Single Celled, Primal, Tribal, "Civilization" (Quite literally), and Galactic.

You are going to spend the majority of your time in the Galactic phase as it is the proverbial "End-Game" to your adventure.

If I had to name any cons for the game, I'd say that each stage up to Galactic is fairly shallow, but in all honesty, this is a rather small complaint because although the game boasts having mutliple stages, it's not a "Civilazation" game, the stages are a "means to an end" so to speak.

My favorite stage is the Galactic stage, simply because once you've gotten to this point, you've kind of "grown" with your Creature race and Galactic boasts the most features of any of the stages.

The Galactic Adventures DLC essentially adds MMO-esque elements to the Galactic Stage, adding in Fetch-Quests, Escort Quests and the ability to get off on alien planets. While this is cool to break up the monotany of space trading and travel every once in awhile, even with community made quests, you are probably going to play the same 3 or 4 over, and over again.

Overall, Spore is a game that is very much remembered but often overlooked for how good it really was. 8/10.

helpfulness: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Simply put: this game contains nearly endless amounts of character customization, and that is why I continue to come back to it over and over. Let your imagination be your guide. You can literally spend 100% of your playing time (like I often do, myself) just designing a multitude of different creatures, vehicles (land, sea, and space) and buildings as well. The game reminded me a lot of Black and White, which I used to play near-obessively when I was younger. 

There's more to the game than just customization and character design, of course. Following the evolutionary story mode itself presents all sorts of interesting scientific, biological, and sociological mechanics. As a gamer, it's the ultimate sense of creative control to supervise and influence a creature's growth and development, along with all the cultural and societal changes that go along with it. It's just so enthralling to raise a creature from infantile stage as a microbe, all the way to a prim-and-proper gentleman of a monster.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												It's a great game. But $20 is a little bit pushing it.

Well, there are tons of sales, and as I'm writing this there's one right now, so you might want to wait for one.

Gameplay:
Evolving your creature is something I found super fun. The graphics are really nice and the animals are cute....most of the time...

I also love the feature that your behavior effects your reputation as a species, you might be a vicious killer, or a very social creature that likes friends.

Unfortunatly, personally I find the extreme change of gamplay a little boring. It starts off as you evolving, killing or befriending other creatures, and eating them or plants. Then it locks the way you look and that's kind of sad, transforming it into a full on tactical birds-eye view of your planet, defending off enemies, and eventually going into..space?

So I see what to developers were doing, a little cell in the ocean to advanced beings in space, but it just didn't seem all that interesting to me at that point.

Depending on what you like, it has an ok replayibility level, but I like going into create and making my own cool animals.

helpfulness: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												TL;DR : This is not a game; it's an environment in which you can admire your creature-making and vehicle-making skills in cool situations.  It's very repetetive, but the scope of the game allows for it to be somehow addictive once you reach the space-age.  So yeah, it's great for very casual gamers, but anyone who wants to experience interesting gameplay will find this game lacking.  Pick it up if it's a couple quid, but I wouldn't pay full-price for it.  Also, ignore the expansion packs.

This isn't really one cohesive game, but a series of mini-games, so I'll just review each one seperately:

Cellular Stage: 
No fun at all, but it's designed as a tutorial to introduce you to the creature-creation and DNA mechanics; swim towards stuff in 2D to get points once your creature auto-eats it - other creatures for 'bad'/'carnivore' points, plants for 'good'/'herbivore' points; a mixture for 'neutral'/'omnivore' points.

Creature Stage: 
Like the cellular stage, but 3D, and to get the 'good' points, you have to sing, dance and pose your way into getting other creatures to like you.  Creature customisation gets real here and you spend most of your time wandering around picking up skeletons to unlock new parts.  This is the most boring stage IMHO due to it's repetition.

Tribal Stage: 
Exactly like the creature stage apart from instead of unlocking new parts, you unlock buildings to give you weapons to kill, or instruments to win over other tribes; it's only less boring than the creature stage because it passes much more quickly.

Civilisation Stage:
The overall point of this stage is the same as the tribal stage, but you also get to design vehicles (land / sea / air) and buildings - as the modelling is the most fun part of the whole game, this is real fun.  You have a -little- bit of resource management as when you're putting the buildings in your city, there's an optimal pattern. It also introduces the 'diplomacy' mechanic which is basically 'get people to like you by giving them money, and then ask them to give you everything they own'.  This bit goes by in a flash, but that's good because the most fun part is...

Space Stage:
This is basically where you apply everything at once - you build spaceships, buildings, vehicles, and even new creatures (once you get the 'creature tweaker' tool for your spaceship).  You can basically take over the whole galaxy by terraforming each planet and putting down colonies...which is fun and satisfying for the first few times, but once you get your first million bucks everything becomes VERY easy and the game stops being fun to play.  

It doesn't stop being addictive, however, because you still find yourself saying things like "If I make my main spaceship look like a star destroyer, can I try and befriend every other alien race who's ships are TIE-fighters so I can fly around with an Imperial fleet?" and you spend the next several hours exploring the galaxy finding / uplifting new races; or you set yourself the task of entirely wiping out the 'big bad' Grox...which I think is impossible, but still.

So yeah, I mean...it's a really great casual game, but if you're after any depth at all you will end up disappointed.  It is very cool flying around in an X-Wing though, and painting every planet white...and setting the ground units to imperial walkers and the air-units to Snow Speeders so you can re-enact the battle of Hoth...

7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
8 people found this review funny
body:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												The first thing everyone asks (or should ask) about a game is "what kind of game is it?".

Spore((tm) is, well, Spore(tm).It doesn't fit into any one genre, apart from possibly sandbox.There's no other game like it.

NOTE: Only mouse over spoilers if you feel you can handle mature content.Swear words can make your head explode if you're not careful.

When starting my Spore(tm) game, I chose a planet and a difficulty.I chose "easy", because I'm a wimp and I'd never played the game before.
Asteroids pelted the planet of my choice in a melodramatic armaggedon, making craters and levelling mountains, splashing into the oceans.

The camera zoomed in...in...in...it was deep under the ocean...an asteroid cracked open...and a sperm fused with a corn dog (spermdog?) popped out of the asteroid.

Oh wait.That's me.

I swam around, chomping up algae and chunks of unnameable meat indiscriminately, until I came across a cell far too big to be legally called a cell (you imposter!).It attempted to swallow me in its ginormous mandibles (of which it had far too many), and I could only swim away, flagella wiggling at  top speed.

Eventually I got away, and the game told me to "call a mate".I did, and my spermdog sent out a little screech, met another spermdog, and got ready for some lovin'.
To all you perverts out there: don't get your hopes up, they just dance around and lay an egg.Sexy.

I was allowed to make some tweaks to my cell's design.I gave it spikes, a third eye, and an electric butt.He then hatched from an egg cell thing.

This went on for a few minutes, until suddenly my triklopticus (for that is what I named him) grew a brain and started wishing for legs.I then advanced to the Creature stage, which consisted of adding legs to an already absurd design, and watched a dozen little leggy spermdogs run up onto dry land.

The Creature stage kept the "mating" mechanic, but I was now running around on dry land eating stuff and meeting other species.I had the option of making friends with them or eating them.

After ten minutes the ground was littered with cute little cadavers.

Eventually, the triklopticus developed into beaked scorpion-like creatures with two legs and arms I named the Ornitank.
Then they became vaguely humanoid, and when my brain had sufficiently increased in size, I moved on to the Tribe stage and was treated to a cutscene of my Ornitanks discovering fire.I was allowed to give them clothes, because they'd just invented pants, too.

This is where the game took on an Age of Empires twist.I had around six tribesmen, all living in a little hut.I could put stuff around the hut and demand that a baby be made (in which case hearts would appear around the hut, an egg would roll out the door, and hatch) and equip my tribesmen with weapons or instruments.I could put them to work hunting or gathering.

I made friends with two neighbouring villages, using the power of music, and three attacked me.Three were burnt down.
For ever village allied or destroyed, my totem pole got bigger.

Before long, my tribesmen were discussing weapons of mass destruction and plotting to take over the world.They grow up so fast *sniff*.

I designed buildings to place in my city in such a way as to increase my income and built an armada of tanks, planes, and ships (also custom designed) to conquer other cities.I gave my Ornitanks new clothes that were slightly more "civilised" (among the options I could have chosen was a large blonde moustache) and discovered that the Creature Creator had a "create animated avatar" option, so I turned my Ornitank citizen into an animated avatar.

After conquering the world, the Ornitanks turned their attention to the stars and inexplicably invented a spaceship that could go between the stars and only take a few minutes doing so (the ship, by the way, is customisable, like creatures, vehicles, and buildings).I made first contact with an alien race that ignored my ship, because they were in the middle of some kind of world war.I sucked one of them up in my tractor beam and dropped him off on my homeworld, for in the Space stage, I am a  very responsible starship captain!

I found a spacefaring race that was big and pink with one eye and a freaky mouth, who spoke to me in a high-pitched voice and asked me to eliminate the infect Doughball! to gain their allegiance (apparently Doughball! is misspelt without the exclamation mark) and so after missions from the aliens and my own race (one of which was terraforming a planet) I set up a trade route and an alliance.However, my only complaint about the space age is that after the game spends so long increasing the scale, you end up playing as a captain on a random ship.The best part is going down onto planets that aren't spacefaring and just straight-up abducting people.On top of that, you unlock crop circles and can just zap them onto planets.I kept going to Civilization Stage planets and using the crop circle tool to fuel any alien conspiracy theorists that may/may not exist.

And that is how you go from spermdog to galactic god in less than three days.

body:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Um dos melhores jogos de simulação que já joguei. Joguei muito mesmo quando criança (ele é um pouquinho "old" , mas é gold, certeza). Em comparação a outros jogos, ele tem uma temática diferente. Segue a teoria da Evolução, em que você cria um ser vivo e de tempos em tempos ele desenvolve habilidades e suas proles nascem mais inteligentes. Porém Spore é divido em uma espécie de estágios, em que você simula coisas diferentes daquela espécie que você criou (estágios em que você é só uma pobre célula dependente e vivente na água, depois você já se adapta à terra, depois tem uma família, uma população toda  e por fim um planeta - sim você brinca com a galáxia- ). Com Spore você não fica naquela "mesmisse" o tempo todo como The Sims ( e sim, é da mesma empresa desenvolvedora Maxis). Bom, para não ficar com uma descrição muito subjetiva, segue abaixo um vídeo perfeitamente explicativo. Ele te toma meia horinha mas tenha paciência, porque vale a pena (a não ser que você realmente não goste do gênero). Por fim, é um jogo divertidíssimo, fácil de mexer e gostoso de jogar (com deliciosos efeitos sonoros e uma rotação de câmera divina -não que isso seja muita coisa).
Divirta-se e brinque com a Genética do Darwin  :3


	
	
		YouTube™ Video: Spore : Vale ou não a pena jogar 
		
			Views: 652,703
