666 of 760 people (88%) found this review helpful
2 people found this review funny
body:
Posted: 20 May, 2014
												An asteroid hurdles through space, speeding past alien spacecraft who follow it, attempting to scan it for any life. Within seconds, the asteroid is out of sight, and enters the orbit of a planet. Catching fire, it slams into the ground, creating a crater from the impact. Hundreds of small fragments explode from the asteroid, scattering themselves around the planet. Some land by cities of sophisticated, lizard-like beigns, others by curious tribes who begin worshipping the fiery rocks, and by clueless creatures who poke and lick them. One particular fragment lands in a small pool of water, and you crawl out - a small, slithery cell who's main goal is to survive. 
This is Spore, the tale of how your microscopic race can go from scavengers getting enough food to barely survive, to a thriving empire that controls the entire galaxy. The game is based on five stages: Cell, Creature, Tribe, Civilization, and Space. Cell station is where your journey begins. There is little customization in this stage, except for the basic shape of your cell and organelles. Once you become the top of the food chain, you evolve legs. Stumbling onto land, you enter the Creature Stage.
 Here is where the true customization takes place. You can collect various parts from skeletons scattered around the planet and add them to your creature. You can make a huge, strong behemoth who crushes his enemies with his gigantic claws, or a small, nimble beign that flies and steals food from his enemies before they notice he is there. You can create your creature based on your species' diet: omnivore, carnivore, or herbivore. Besides the customization, Creature Stage introduces a huge skill in the game that is incredibly useful - friends and foes. 
You can choose whether to impress other races and become friends, or attempt to destroy and annhilate them. You have to be wise as to who you attack and who you ally; making enemies with all the weak creatures could end up with them evolving into way stronger creatures and destroying YOU. Once your brain has increased, your species can begin laying out the foundations for a tribe. Here is where the friends and foes system comes into major effect. To complete the Tribal Stage and become a civilization, you must complete your Tribe Totem Pole. For every tribe you defeat or ally, a new totem is added. This stage goes by rather fast, and prepares you for Civilizational Stage. 
Civilization Stage takes inspiration from Sid Meier's Civilization series. Your goal is to control every city on the planet, whether through religious, economic, or military means. Religious races can convert the race into believing your civilization is their leader, and is considered the easiest way to complete the stage. Military is just brute force; when it comes to the guns in this, size DOES matter. Economic is peaceful; you start a trade route with a friendly city and eventually buy their city from them. This takes longer than the other two ways but can be very helpful in the long run.
Once you control the planet, you can launch a space project, starting the Space Stage, which is endless. All the choices you've made in the previous stages add up to decide what class you are in the Space Stage - perhaps a battle-crazed tyrant, or a religious zealot out to convert everyone to the teachings of Spode. During the stage, your goal is to go from the Captain of your Space Project to the Omnipotent Beign of the Universe. On the way, you'll encounter the Grox - a cyborg race who hate all and arguably are the antagonists of the game. (If hours of work are put into it, you could make them your ally- if you ever do, I commend you for your bravery.) Between space pirates, colonizing other planets, upgrading your fleet, and stabalizing your funds, this is by far my favorite stage. Overall, this is a great game for creative people and truly lets your imagination soar.

Graphics: 16/20
Story: 17/20
Gameplay: 20/20
Replayability: 19/20
Soundtrack: 18/20
Overall: 90/100

												The game is a great game, at first... My first 9 hours into the game got me hooked, but once i started space exploration, the game got EXTREMELY boring and repetitive. Sure the galaxy is HUGE and there's soooo much to explore, but after a few hours in space, the same thing happens over and over no matter where you go. The replay value just simply isn't there. Edit: If I had just bought the spore game itself without the expansions/dlc (which would amount to $5 on sale), then i could say the game was worth it. So my recommendation to you guys would be to just buy the $5 spore game and not the entire package.

body:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												It's fantastic being able to design and play as your own creatures.  The design possibilities are nearly limitless.  Creating and messing around briefly as your creatures is really the only great part about this game.  The Cell, Tribal, Civ, and Space stages are mostly just disappointing and tedious.  If you have a day free, you can play all the way from Cell stage to Space stage in a single sitting.  Space is agreeably the worst part of the game sense you are set as a single ship managing your entire empire. (And no expansion fixes that)  

I'm pretty upset that they gave up on this franchise.  I feel like it could have easily become amazing and complex over generations like the Sims franchise. 

TL:DR Only get this game when it's on sale.

Your key for the game may not work and the multiplayer servers don't work.

No, you will not get a refund, it's not Steam's fault. It's Maxis and EA's but you won't get a refund from them either and no the game will not be patched so don't bother whining about that. People are buying the game regardless if they patch it, they have no reason to spend extra money to fix it.

body:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Summary: 4 Mini-games plus one giant bore.
Multiplayer: No
Completion: Never ends, but I stopped at 20 hrs.
Cards: No
Cloud: No

Spore is one of those rare games that within 5 minutes of playing it, I felt like I had to complete it. I genuinely enjoyed the beginning stages of the game, but that rush progressively became less and less enchanting with each progressing age.

The game is essentially 4 mini-games strung together with 1 giant never-ending game at the end. You start out as a single-cell organism struggling for survival in a world of eat-or-be-eaten. It's a nice, relaxing evolution game, and to be honest, I would have been perfectly fine if the majority of the game was like this. But this age is over all too soon and you'll find yourself on taking your first steps on land.

As a terrestrial creature, new challenges arise. It's time to make friends, kill enemies, fight for survival, and forage for food. It's a good progression from the cell stage an it's kind of fun, but not as much as the previous age. Soon, your species will propogate to the point of having their own town. Around this point the game feels like a stripped-down RTS game. You gather resources, forge alliances, crush clans, and expand. It's a rather awkward stage and the gameplay itself is also so radically different that it almost feels out of place.

The civlization stage is similar to the tribal stage, but you have entire cities and vehicles to do your bidding. Rather than playing like an RTS game, now it feels like a stripped-down Civlization game. You get to do some major customization now, but it's all cosmetic. As you near the end of the stage, the time comes to launch your first rocket.

The Space Age makes up the bulk of the game. Now a space-faring race, you do pretty much what you were doing before but on a much grander scale. Hundreds of planets to explore, most of them look the same-ish, and to be honest, this is easily the most boring part of the game. Play as a Fedex service, do some feng shui on planets, become a trader, there's so much to do in this stage... and yet there's no real goal, other than than reaching a certain part of the galaxy, but the game will still go on regardless.

Overall, Spore is... difficult for me to rate. The parts I liked, I liked a lot. The parts I disliked, I got bored to tears. What began as a fun evolution game ultimately ends up as a chore. The amount of micromanagement magnifies tenfold with each passing stage, and since the game changes radically with each stage, it's constantly throwing new stuff at you, while simultaneously rendering old knowledge irrelevant. I'm sure many people enjoy the endgame, but definitely not me. I give this a 7/10.

body:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Really enjoyed spore. It came out many years ago, on my birthday and I had my dad get it for my present when I was younger. It was really a fun game, I enjoyed it a lot, and I enjoy it even better now that I have a better computer. The graphics are chunky, and that's just what makes it's style!

Good:
-------------------------------------------
+Make custom creatures
+Literally customize anything, you want it's toe to be huge, but the legs to be small? GO FOR IT.
+Runs basically on any pc, it's such an old game.
+Graphics look nice actually, on my Gx950 graphics card.
+Each mode is indepth, so you can get different endings and benefits depending on the path you took.
+You can technically upload your creations and download others.

Bad:
--------------------------------------------
+I havent personally been able to log into my EA account, so I play offline.

+This game isn't what people wanted it to be - but it's good for those who don't care what it was 'supposed' to be. My husband and I played this as young teens, and we enjoyed a lot for what it was.

+ Multiple ending types, and creature spawns can be good, but it can feel old after a while with the AI being similar each game.

body:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Spore is a great game. I've been playing for over 24 hours now in total across Spore and Spore: Galactic Adventures. You start off as a cell, evolve into higher level species and eventually become a spacefaring civilization. I've learned a few different things about the game that I feel newer players could have use of knowing.

Evolve your creature to max in the creature stage if you plan on playing with Galactic Adventures. You will be using creature stage abilities a lot here, better make sure that it becomes as easy as possible for you.
Save often. Spore crashes occasionally, and with the immersiveness of the game, it's easy to forget to save. Spore does NOT have auto-save functionality.
One more thing that a lot of people miss: BACK UP YOUR SPORE DATA FOLDERS! I had the game suddenly delete all my progress in Spore without any warning. I don't know the programming logic that would result in such a thing happening, but when I launched Spore yesterday, I was greeted with the main menu with no saves in it. Luckily I already had an older backup of the data as I copied it for playing on another computer once, but I've lost a lot of progress.
Spore data folders may be found at %appdata%\Spore as well as "My Spore Creatures" in your Documents folder. Back them up regularly.

body:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												After finally feeling I have put in enough time to review this game I want to go a bit in depth. first let's look positive: on the plus side the cell stage made me nostalgic for the eat and row games I played as a young child. The creature stage I found thoroughly fun and enjoyable. The combat is quite simplistic and easy to navigate if your on a full red streak. Befriending creatures was fluid as well but I haven't done all that much. The user interface I found nice and friendly and had no troube navigating menus. The space stage made me feel quite free and I loved it but it definitely had its bad points.
The negatives now: the space stage was too long and I ended up choosing a planet not on looks but on what was closest to the centre, it also suffers from bad combat, a huge difficulty spike and monotony. The civ stage was too restrictive and I found boring and I won't go into the god awful village stage.

Overall I really enjoyed this game and would definitely recommend it to friends especially if it's cheap it still holds up great and you can be so so creative with it if you have the money buy it for sure.

body:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Very interesting game to play...really brings out your creative side. When you first start playing, your first reaction is usually, "Awwww! It's so cute!" or, "Oh my god It's going to eat me!" Let me say that this game is very realistic, and if you love animals, or "creatures" you should surely choose to be an herbivore. You choose from Carnivore, Herbivore, and Omnivore. Sometimes you'll say, "Ugh, there's too much going on!" or, "Give me a break!" But in the end things will calm down and you will begin enjoying the game a lot more once you get the hang of it and what to do and what not to do...the easiest way, and the hardest way. Once you get to space though, the game's pace slows down considerably. You get into kind of a routine and begin doing the same thing over and over again. Some quit at that point, and just keep creating games and stopping at space, but if you get past the more boring or slow-paced parts, it gets fun and "not-so-boring." All in all, if you like a game with plenty of chances to show off your creativity, I would definitely recommend this game.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Simply put: this game contains nearly endless amounts of character customization, and that is why I continue to come back to it over and over. Let your imagination be your guide. You can literally spend 100% of your playing time (like I often do, myself) just designing a multitude of different creatures, vehicles (land, sea, and space) and buildings as well. The game reminded me a lot of Black and White, which I used to play near-obessively when I was younger. 

There's more to the game than just customization and character design, of course. Following the evolutionary story mode itself presents all sorts of interesting scientific, biological, and sociological mechanics. As a gamer, it's the ultimate sense of creative control to supervise and influence a creature's growth and development, along with all the cultural and societal changes that go along with it. It's just so enthralling to raise a creature from infantile stage as a microbe, all the way to a prim-and-proper gentleman of a monster.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I really tried to love this game. It is cute, funny, open-ended, and explores new grounds for videogames. If anything, it is admirable. But is it fun? The mechanics in every evolutionary stage are rather shallow and repetitive, the strategy components are severly limited and the action components reduced to a few button presses once in a while. Exploration falls flat too since the procedural planets are boring and samey.
The draw of this game for many seems to be the character creator, as evident by the slew of creature videos on youtube, and it is entertaining for a while, but cannot hold my attention for long.
In the end, it is suprisingly... boring.

body:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												I like game, but beware EA didn't put a whole lot of effort into this game and it crashes rampantly. I highly suggest you save very often or else you'll end up like me and be into the tribal stage when your game crashes and whisks away all your progress down the drain. EA dropped the ball so much that apparently there isn't even an autosave function. This game crashes so much and personally i don't think I'll ever be playing it again. The game itself is very fun as you get to guide the evolution of your species from a single cellular organization all the way to space faring god. EA made a lot of promises about this game that they didn't deliver. So pretty much standard EA behavior.

Pros:
+ Engaging gameplay
+ Enjoyable & somewhat diverse scenarios
+ Diversity among creature creations
+ Looks good for something made in 2008
+ Lots of unique body parts to chose from
+ Species specialization (e.g. carnivore, omnivore, herbivore)
+ Different creatures/species have different "voices" (diversity of creature communications)
+ Decent job explaining functions of everthing through all stages

Cons:
- Stages of evolution rather short
- Space stage the longest stage (Dispropotionate compared to other stages)
- Cannot continue to gain the evolution points to unlock body parts once you complete a stage
- Only real option once completing a stage is advancing the evolution
- Rather odd taking over planets in Space stage with your single ship
- Actually rather odd doing everthing in the Space stage from your single ship
- Rampant crashes
- No autosave feature
- Very few save slots for different worlds
- Too few stages of evolution
- Almost zero interaction available during Space stage with nonspace faring civilizations

body:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a Rocky Road Bar:
1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

												It was a great game in its prime, but since EA stopped giving a ♥♥♥♥ about the entire project, Maxis died, and no one actually patches the game anymore - many game-breaking glitches will erase all of your progress in a snap (as Autosaves simply don't exist in game.)

I don't reccomend the game whatsoever in its current state, but I certainly would have 3 years ago. Get it while on sale for when it's less than 10 dollars, but otherwise - stay far away. $20 is a lot to pay for something that barely runs on any Modern PC.

It's a huge shame, too. Back when it was still being updated and cared about by the developers, Spore was possibly one of the best creature-based games you could get.

body:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I am extremely happy to own this game on Steam.I probably spent hundreds of hours playing this game throughout all of it's stages.

Spore is a rather complex game even if it comes off as a bit childish.

It has 5 completely different game stages:

In the first one you start as a cell trying to survive.As you progress,you start to evolve into a multicellular organism,develpoing more and more features like better eyes,horns and so on.In the end your ''fish'' will evolve enough for it to go on land.

This is where the second stage of the game begins.You are now a land animal fighting/socialising with other species and exploring the world.Same as in the first stage you evolve continuously.

The Third stage,is the tribal stage.Your animal is smart enough to form a tribe,craft tools,build houses and create a form of government.Your mission is to conquer the surrounding area by war or diplomacy.

After that,the fourth stage begins.Now you must conquer the entire planet by the same principle.But now along war and diplomacy,you can establish your domination by trade.This stage represents the stage we are in.Tanks,nuclear bombs and lots of trading.

Now begins the space age.You now control the entire solar system and begin exploring the Milky Way galaxy.This is by far the best stage of the game because of it's depth.It is for sure addictive to explore planets and venture into the unknown meeting space empires,undeveloped planets and so on.You can terraform planets,blow them up,colonise them or just explore for artifacts and more hidden items.

The game is fun but it has it's weak points.It could have been so much more.The tribe and industrial age stages are dull and unremarkable.They play as RTS games with a bit of diplomacy mixed in there.Nothing special and it could have been much improved.

This game is a unique sandbox space exploration simulator and my only regret is that Maxis limited themselves when creating this game.It could have been one of the best games of the 2000's..let's hope they plan a Spore 2.

The seemingly unlimited customization combined with tons of free user created content gives the game amazing replay-ability.I recommend this game to everyone.At least to try it once.

body:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Spore is by far one of the best sandbox evolution based survival games I've played. Given that I haven't heard of any other games that pursue this kind of playstyle, my review may be slightly biased. You will start off as a single cell that has been brought to your planet by a meteorite. You can choose between playing as a carnivore or an herbivore. In the first stage (Cell) the carnivore is argueably the better choice because there will be plenty of creatures to eat, and you get parts to add to your cell faster this way. The currency in this stage is DNA points, which can be gained by eating plants (herbivore) or meat (carnivore). Once you have filled the progress bar to full, you will advance to the creature stage. In this stage, your cell evolved into a creature and migrates onto land with a group of your species. You are able to add legs and arms in this stage, and can add a filter mouth or jaw in order to make your species into an omnivore. I highly recommend this because you are not stuck with being forced to find animals to kill or migrate to find more fruit to eat. The currency in this stage is the same as the currency in the cell stage, however is gained by allying groups or destroying them. Once you have finished the creature stage through defeating or allying other groups of animals, you will transition to the tribal stage! In this stage you band together with your group and make alliances with other tribes or exterminate them. There is a wide array of tools available to choose from in this stage, from fishing spears, to stone axes, to healing rods. All of them serve various functions and your main currency to purchase these buildings is food. Which can either be gathered from the wild or plundered from enemy villages. Once you have finished the tribal stage, you will advance to the civilization stage! In this stage, the tribes you either destroyed or allied will band together to form your first city! You get to design a lot in this stage. The town hall, factories, houses, entertainment, boats, cars, airplanes! It's all at your fingertips! The main currency in this stage is called Sporebucks. This is earned by selling spice, the hot commodity in spore, which is produced by geysers on your planet. Eventually, other groups of your species will arise with their own cities. You can either choose to ally them, purchase their city through economic means, convert their city through religious means, or force their city into submission through military means. How you played each stage determines which kinds of special abilities that you have. In the civilization stage, the way you played the tribal stage determines whether you are a militant or religious city. How you caputure an enemy city determines its specialization. Or for instance you capture a military city by religious means, you can choose whether it is a military city or a religious city. Once you have achieved total global domination, you will advance to the space stage! Most people dislike the space stage because it's "boring" or "too different from previous stages". I think it is the most fun stage because you can purchase star systems, plant colonies, craft planets to your liking, discover other empires, destroy lesser empires, uplift a species in a lower stage to a higher one, terraform planets that were 150 degrees Celsious to a comfortable 22 degrees, control the spice empire through taking ownership of the high profit spice planets, defeat the evil Grox empire guarding the center of the galaxy, and so much more! People dislike it because it takes so long, but that's the fun of it. You are but a single planet in a galaxy of tens of thousands! Have fun, explore! They've even included the Solar System for you to find (I've found it)! After playing this game for over a week now, I've expanded my empire to a measly 30ish systems. I look forward to conquering the Grox and expanding my fruitful empire to the farthest reaches of the galaxy.

tl;dr A great game with tons of customization as you expand from a cell to a galactic superpower.

10/10

body:
Posted: March 23
												This game is too quick in terms of progression from cellular organism to space-faring creature. Once you get to space, it's the same shake-and-bake colony making: find planet suitable for life, terraform, colonize, and... do it all over again!

In other words, once you get to the "end-game" portions of the game, it ends up being very repetitive and boring. Given that EA's servers for the game are also apparently dead, and there being no Steam Workshop at the time of this writing, you don't get to share with others.

Basically, the game's missing key features now, there's no support for it, and the DLC content where your space captain goes on adventures is so clunky and buggy, I can't recommend this game anymore.

If the game is ever on sale, it might be worth picking up if you've never played it before. Don't get me wrong; the game is fun, it's just that the fun doesn't last after you've done 2 or 3 civilizations.

The verdict: this game might be worth $5 if you find yourself playing with character creation screens way too long. Otherwise, spend your hard-earned cash elsewhere.

body:
Posted: 16 September, 2015
												I didn't build my empire, I took it. Tearing it from the grasp of the species around me. What I couldn't buy with money I bought with the blood of the innocent. 

My empire was pure; only the clean survived. My empire was strong; I sifted the weak away like chaff. My empire was vast; we spread our might to the farthest corners of the galaxy.

We were a people of pure war. Gunfire was our music, the smell of smoke and charred flesh was the sweetest of aromas, and the site of corpses and ruins was the most beautiful sight there was. The universe was our canvas and we painted it with blood. Death was our peace and destruction was our prosperity. 

We made petty alliances with the other, impure species in the galaxy. We used them to do our bidding. The smiled as they went to their deaths. Then while they were busy, we claimed what was rightfully ours. We tore down their homes and slaughtered their people. It was but mere amusment to the wars we had seen. Just something to pass the time.

Others we waisted no time with. They were too unclean to be bothered with. They were dirt and we were to clean the universe. We were to scrub their impurity out of the fabric of space and time. Some species fought back, their fights were mightier than others, but still nothing compared to our vast power.

Soon we met the grox, a mighty empire that had claimed the center of the universe. The center of a universe that belonged to us. We waged war. And we do to this day... but that is what we want. After all this time, we met an empire that would wage war on us eternally. And so, our galactic history turned into a galactic love story. A story of two empire who have fallen in love with the war they wage on each other.

10/10 

Will recomend to the corpses of my enemies.

body:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Will Wright's fascination with letting people play god  from SimCity in 1989 to the game that garnered worldwide fame and cemented EA as the top-dog in game publishing for over half a decade, The Sims has led to Spore, the first game where your actions truly feel godlike. But a new Sim game this is not, and this is apparent right from the moment your asteroid fragment breaks apart and you lay eyes on the amoeba-like creature you're going to manifest.At the start, you're prompted to choose between being a carnivore or a herbivore, and that determines whether your little cell starts with a meat-eating jaw or a collection of small tentacle-like appendages for tearing apart microscopic plant matter. You direct your cell around and eat accordingly. Eating and surviving  are the only real objectives for this first section of the game, which plays like an organic blend of fl0w and Pac-Man, and becomes progressively more difficult as your cell becomes multicellular bigger and more complex.Eventually you'll devour enough to grow a (tiny) brain, and advance to the second phase of the game  the creature phase.Immediately taken to the creator, now in 3D your humble little cell can now use a pair of legs. As your new belegged creature wanders landward, with identical friends in tow, you get your first glimpse of your home planet. This phase of the game is more complex, and you must choose between befriending the other species you encounter, and eradicating them from the face of the planet. The latter works similarly to combat in games like World of Warcraft. You've got a set of abilities and when you use an ability, you trigger a cooldown.The third phase the tribal section  works like a small-scale RTS, with resource collecting, unit production and building construction. You must assign villagers various tasks and spend food on hatching new tribe members, or adding to your small pool of buildings. Again you'll meet other tribes, and you'll be forced to choose between allying with them and systematically dismembering them and torching their huts.The entire time you've been playing, the game has tracked your actions and determined various passive and active bonuses for the next part accordingly, and depending on your technique, you'll end up as a military nation, a religious nation or an economic nation.The actual gameplay for this section plays out like a simplified version of Rise of Nations. You capture resource points, build units, and try to take over the other cities with them. The depth lies within the ability to design the layout of the cities, thereby determining how resistant to attacks they are, and how efficient at making money they are. During the final phase of the game, having unified your planet, you once again take control of a single entity and man a spacecraft.here are several introductory missions to get you used to the capabilities of your ship, and before long you're flying between stars and meeting other races. No longer earthbound, you are literally free to do whatever you want. Interaction with other races is much more fleshed out in this section of the game. There are dialogue boxes a la Sid Meier's Civilization where you can choose to trade goods, or take diplomatic actions, and the races each have their own fleshed out personality.In conclusion, Spore is definitely an exciting game in this time of repetitive ideas in an over crowded gaming market. It's not quite an RTS nor an RPG nor a strategy game but one that successfully combines all three genres into an exciting game that works quite well and is complimented with good graphics and a great premise.Overall 9/10.

body:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												I absolutely love creating all sorts of weird monsters and creatures in this game!

That aside, I do love this game, but it's nowhere near perfect. The grindy nature of this particular game genre (God Simulators, etc.) kinda wears thin after a while of playing it, making Spore a game that's better in short bursts. Aside from the creation of critters and buildings, the way the gameplay changes keeps it interesting, and the space level (once you make it) is actually quite deep and complex.

Recommended? Yes, but only if you liked playing with legos as a kid (which should be everyone) or love God Sim games (which definitely isn't everyone's cup of tea).

body:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Amazing.

Pros
- This is the true meaning of 'customizable'.
- You can slowly but surely buy out cities through trading, use your powwer of pink straw hats to spread your religion across the globe, or just blow it all up.
(Same goes for the other mode, you've got choices.)
- Some of your creations show up on other save files. (E.G. a spaceship belonging to a save in Space Stage abducts one of your pets in Tribal stage)
-Several 'stages'
  = Cell stage (Ever heard of Agar.io? That's what this is, but cooler.) Eat anything smaller than you. Run away from anything bigger. Have kids. Grow an extra fin. Repeat.
  = Creature stage: Grow legs and walk around. Hunt a few species to extinction. Make friends with (relative) giants. Get killed by (actual) giants.
  = Tribal stage: Kill everything that moves to death and/or hug everything that moves. (The former is much more reliable, you know.) Also: Avoid the giants.
  = Civilization Stage: A simplified version of Sid Meyer's Civilization for dummies that has been simplified, with more customizability. Watch as your trade routes get torn apart by afforementioned giants.
  = Space Stage: Make your spaceship and conquer/hug the galaxy. Destroy giants with your kickass lasers and nukes.

Cons:
- Creature stage can take FOREVER. (Due to giants.)
- One or two glitches. (Not many)
- A certain cool DLC isn't available anymore.
- The Bor- (What? Did I say Borg? I meant Grox) are overpowered, and you can't get the Genesis Dev- (*Cough cough* The staff of life *Cough cough*) because of them.

body:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												I played this game about 30 hours (on the c&c dlc which is counted as stand-alone game on steam), and a bunch more a few years back, but I feel there could be much more to do: if you get deep into the game it will gift you with at least 40-50 hours of gameplay imho.

Though the First stages might seem the most original and appealing, you may find out instead the space one isn't odd/dull at all. Once you get used to the sci-fi-like RTS aspects of the 2 last levels you'll realise how fun it is to expand your terrestrial empire first and your cosmic one later on.

So to sum up I really loved manipulating the genes to form powerful cells or creatures, and I liked badly to customise my vehicles, citisens and structures (the game really lets you use your skills in architecture and design); but the space stage isn't to be understimated - I promise myself I'll get back to it sometimes as it's the one I played the least.

body:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												This game is providing me with what I have always dreamed of. ABSOLUTE POWER OVER THE ENTIRE GALAXY! if I play my cards right. 
Every stage of this game is good fun. I abolutely love this game.

My only complaint is that in the final stage of the game your empire becomes soo large that personally dealing with every little thing and trying to handle the spice trading for your entire empire with your one player controlled ship really started sucking. I wanted to be able to Age of Empires style delagate responsibilities to computer controlled characters. like trading, like military action, like colonization. I wanted to end up being the emperor who could just watch the empire I had built continue to grow, and spread, and take everything over everything. After the setup and planning you do in the first stages of the game, only require minimal player interaction, which would leave me (the emperor) the freedom to go do whatever I wanted. (like finding galactic adventures and lvling my captain. that was fun.) 

That said, this game is fun and totally worth the cost. Its just not made to allow you to be able take over the galaxy to the scale that I had wanted, in other words its sort of soft-capped out. There comes a point when you reach a size where you simply cannot manage everything personally, and you start losing planets as fast as you are gaining them.

helpfulness:
2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
1 person found this review funny
body:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												Purchased on disc back at launch. Repurchased on Steam a while back. All my creations are still cloud saved, and can reuse my old designs from 8 years ago. A+. 10/10

As for gameplay, I have broken it down to each stage below:

Cell stage is fun, Pac-man-esque without the wall barriers, fun, simple, neat.

Creature stage is okay, slightly tedious if your are the sort of player that needs EVERY type of body part before continuing. 

Tribe stage is very much a one-trick wonder. Don’t over think it, complete quickly, move on.

City stage is kinda fun, building cities quickly becomes a copy paste exercise, but tearing down the cities of your enemies through commerce, religion or focer is all equally satisfying!

Space stage is the pinnacle of the game, you start with very little, you must work and manage trade routes, and blasting cities apart on neighbouring system to progress. Money starts tight, and pew-pew sounds easier; but allies do help early-mid game. Micro managing planetary spice is annoying to set up, but satisfying  when the wonga rolls in. Ecological disasters and space pirate raiding keeps you from rushing away from home too quickly. The balance is  good between feeling far too easy, and flipping around to a point where a new disaster happens every few minutes. 

I haven’t got to the end yet. This is definitely a game worth the £15 price tag, from a person who paid full brick and mortar retail at launch. If it’s on sale, snap it up.

												[Clocked in only 5 hours because I transferred to the galactic launcher but finished my first playthrough using only Spore features not galactic ones]

It's a very enjoyable game especially if you love civilization games. Here you start as a freakin single celled organism.

What I love with the early stages of the game is that your creature evolves from that single celled organism to whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want to go with until tribal age.

I must say tribal stage up to space age the game changed for me, you stopped evolving and instead start using clothes.

Spage Age I must say is pretty freakin huge!!! So huge I can't explore it all and that's just a single galaxy.

As you go further in your own civilization you notice less and less species surround you (extiction is common even in outer space because of sentient beings being ♥♥♥♥♥)

Recommendations:
You should grab Galactic Adventures expansion as it becomes bland after exploring different sectors.
If you want the online feature to work, put the game product code you have on steam (you can get it on the CD key of your game [library->games->spore->CD key]) and put it on origin (Origin->add game->put the product code). (there's not much with the online feature though)

Regret:

I didn't get to kill humans!

body:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												For the record, my hours with this game with the GA expansion are DISPROPORTIONATELY HUGE compared to what's being shown here. Like, 600+ hours.

Absolutely love this game, I never stop coming back to play it.
I will admit, when I first got this game, oh, 4-ish years ago, I was expecting a tad bit more out of it than I saw. Then again, Spore, in and of itself was an INCREDIBLY ambitious game in its early stages. It's not the perfect, all-encompassing game some, like me, might hope it to be, but it is incredibly fun and incredibly challanging on the higher difficulties, ESPECIALLY in space, which is pretty much nigh impossible to completely "finish", lest you have no life whatsoever. It's nice and kid-friendly with the cartoonish creature designs, and the quick gameplay up to the space stage is a boon for casual gamers. But for those of us seeking to conquer the galaxy, and get the real sense of action and adventure, the space stage has enough alien genocides, nuclear explosions, and planet busting for even the most hardcore 4X strategy gamer. It's an enjoyable game with a nice mix of everything and quite a few challenges mixed in. If nothing else, play it for the space stage; probably the best, least mundane part of the game.

The DLCs add some nice features as well; the new adventure feature in Galactic Adventures adds an interesting new level of complexity and depth to the already complex space stage, and makes nice use of the creature properties you all thought were going to be useless after the creature stage.

Side note, FINALLY managed to make a decent-looking human with the in-game parts - a painful ordeal, to be sure.

Oh, and make sure not to ♥♥♥♥ off the Grox if you like your ♥♥♥ where it is.

Posted: November 30, 2015
												EA and Origin accounts made since 2013 DO NOT connect to spore. User created content is unviewable. EA knows about this and has been sitting on this since July of this year. You also cannot create a new account.

Of course I didn't know about that til after the fact, at least you can be an informed consumer.

EDIT:

Was directed to a forum post to fix the issues I was having. It worked! http://steamcommunity.com/app/17390/discussions/0/490123938445529635/#p2
Kudos to KoolAidtheRed

Despite that, it doesn't excuse EA making things extremely difficult not only to find out what is wrong, but getting around to fixing it. In the end I'd say go ahead and get this game if you only want half the functionality or if you have the tech-savy to fix it.

helpfulness: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Spore may not be what I was expecting. It may not be as good as I thought it could be. But once I looked past the dissappointment, I realised that there is still a good game here.

Let me get the things that upset me out of the way. The Creature stage seems to last too long with little variation. You either kill everyone around you, or charm them. And charming is a bit confusing, so it always boils down to me killing off races of animals and watching the progress bar rise ever so slightly each time.

Space stage is practically pointless. I feel that there is no goal in it. Sometimes, there are parts of space you can't  get to because they are just a tiny bit too far away. Cell stage was funner than both of these, which is pretty sad. City Stage is too short. It only lasts an hour and a half, at the most. Which sucks, because it's my favorite stage. You get to command vehicles you created to destroy other cities and conquer them. But the biggest danger in City Stage is turrets, not enemy vehicles.

That's about it for the things I dislike, so on the the praising for Spore's creativity.
CREATING THINGS IS GREAT. They made spinoffs based only on the Spore Creators, and there is a reason for that. You can construct creatures ranging from spiders with dolphin heads to dragons with butterfly wings and a human nose. It's great. The Vehicle Creators are my absolute favorite part of the game. I have created Spaceships of every shape and size, and i am proud of them. You will never see the same ship twice, unless someone actually made a duplicate. I feel like the game would be cooler if more people played and interacted, creating new creatures, buildings (oh yeah, you can create buildings. not my favorite.), and vehicles. But that's just me. Maybe? People, join me, i'm lonely.

Spore is not a bad game, as long as you are creative and can deal with a bit of boring gameplay early on. You can create endless creatures, vehicles, and building with endless variety. The Tribal and City stages are fun, but short. good thing you can repeat them any time. I give Spore a 6/10, and I do recommend this game.
(this is my first long review)

helpfulness: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I do rather love this game, but I won't recommend it.

I remember back when it was still in development and little by little sneak peeks were shown and it looked amazingly awesome... and then when it came out it (like so many other games) had been significantly dumbed down for a less complex more mainstream gameplay. Even so there was (and still is) a huge amount of delight to be had in raising your creatures from single celled organisms, chosing their skills by rewriting their DNA from generation to generation until they become civilized and then developing them into the endgame (space exploration) via technological advances.

So why no recommendation?

Well for a start the game is just outright unstable. The general instability just doesn't seem to be fixable. Everywhere I looked I found it was just an accepted side effect of running the game. So it will crash. And it doesn't autosave. So you must save often. And if you screw up and save after it's begun breaking it will destroy that save game and make it forever unloadable. It's also been ditched by EA so it won't be being fixed.

The actual evolutionary stages (barring the last) are just too plain short. I wanted to spend hours on each stage but you zoom forwards, even if you go the completionist route and stick around until you've done every last thing you can. The combat is not great, the social minigame is read a cue and then press one of four buttons (creature stage) three buttons (tribal stage) oh we got rid of the buttons just click on it already (civ stage)

The final space stage is huge and is where you will will either spend most of your time, or where you will get quickly fed up and return to the start to create more creatures. There is literally an entire galaxy to take over including a race of extremely unfriendly borg *cough* sorry, I mean Grox towards to the centre. Your creature, that you poured so much time and attention into is replaced by a spaceship and it all gets a bit meh.... Galactic Adventures does try to address this but not well... (I'll deal with that on it's own though).

Initially you will ooooh over the creature creator. Eventually you will be frustrated by it's limitations and the relatively restrictive set of main parts. The inability to set a gender/voice for your creature is most evidenced when you create something female looking and it talks like a brawny guy or something cute and sounds like it's just waiting to eat you for breakfast. There are a huge number of really minor fixes that could have been added to this that would have provided some huge quality of life improvements for this game... but despite them being suggested over and over again when the game's developers were still active, they were unfortunately never addressed.

I still love Spore. It holds a very special place in my heart, but I can't recommend it. If you still fancy it despite its issues then you'll probably have a great time with it. I'd love to see a sequel - some of the things that were cutting edge when this came out are much more developed now and it could be awesome... unlikely, but still...

body:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Simply put: this game contains nearly endless amounts of character customization, and that is why I continue to come back to it over and over. Let your imagination be your guide. You can literally spend 100% of your playing time (like I often do, myself) just designing a multitude of different creatures, vehicles (land, sea, and space) and buildings as well. The game reminded me a lot of Black and White, which I used to play near-obessively when I was younger. 

There's more to the game than just customization and character design, of course. Following the evolutionary story mode itself presents all sorts of interesting scientific, biological, and sociological mechanics. As a gamer, it's the ultimate sense of creative control to supervise and influence a creature's growth and development, along with all the cultural and societal changes that go along with it. It's just so enthralling to raise a creature from infantile stage as a microbe, all the way to a prim-and-proper gentleman of a monster.

helpfulness: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Spore may not be what I was expecting. It may not be as good as I thought it could be. But once I looked past the dissappointment, I realised that there is still a good game here.

Let me get the things that upset me out of the way. The Creature stage seems to last too long with little variation. You either kill everyone around you, or charm them. And charming is a bit confusing, so it always boils down to me killing off races of animals and watching the progress bar rise ever so slightly each time.

Space stage is practically pointless. I feel that there is no goal in it. Sometimes, there are parts of space you can't  get to because they are just a tiny bit too far away. Cell stage was funner than both of these, which is pretty sad. City Stage is too short. It only lasts an hour and a half, at the most. Which sucks, because it's my favorite stage. You get to command vehicles you created to destroy other cities and conquer them. But the biggest danger in City Stage is turrets, not enemy vehicles.

That's about it for the things I dislike, so on the the praising for Spore's creativity.
CREATING THINGS IS GREAT. They made spinoffs based only on the Spore Creators, and there is a reason for that. You can construct creatures ranging from spiders with dolphin heads to dragons with butterfly wings and a human nose. It's great. The Vehicle Creators are my absolute favorite part of the game. I have created Spaceships of every shape and size, and i am proud of them. You will never see the same ship twice, unless someone actually made a duplicate. I feel like the game would be cooler if more people played and interacted, creating new creatures, buildings (oh yeah, you can create buildings. not my favorite.), and vehicles. But that's just me. Maybe? People, join me, i'm lonely.

Spore is not a bad game, as long as you are creative and can deal with a bit of boring gameplay early on. You can create endless creatures, vehicles, and building with endless variety. The Tribal and City stages are fun, but short. good thing you can repeat them any time. I give Spore a 6/10, and I do recommend this game.
(this is my first long review)

body:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												IF YOU HAVE PROBLEMS RUNNING SPORE:

Go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore" and find the file called "runme.exe". Right click it and set the compatibility mode to Windows XP SP2.
Now go to "C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Spore\SporeBin" and find "SporeApp.exe" - do the same, set the compatibility mode to WinXP SP2.

This should now work. I didn't have to do anything on my Windows 10 x64 machine, but I had to do this for my gf's Win8 machine because nothing else would work.

Hope this helps!

Otherwise - the game is very fun :)

This is easily the worst stage in the game, its slow, monotonous, and annoying, the gameplay is shallow as ♥♥♥♥, the thing feels so much longer than it really is and it just sucks, you can kill other tribes (Once again, ♥♥♥♥ about PETA), and creatures, (PETA)advance as a soicitey, claim some tiki things, make babies, but all of it is executed poorly, its not unplayable, but its not fun either.
Rating:5/10  below average 

Stage 4: OH GOD ITS A RTS AGAIN WH- oh nevermind this is done well.
Yep, I LIKE the civilization stage even tough most hate it and even tough i hated the tribal stage, you are probably very confused right now but allow me to explain. You see it may be a RTS again but this time its a GOOD RTS, the gameplay is intresting and deep, the...... um.... well there isnt much to say, I geuss im bad at this ♥♥♥♥. The civilization stage takes place during your species era of civilization holy ♥♥♥♥ mind blown more specificly around the time of it where we live in, you start with a rover thingamajiger and make it get spice, then ♥♥♥♥ gets intresting now in this stage, this might shock you but........... its worth not just killing everything  YOU TRATIOR YOU WORK WITH PETA DONT YOU?! ok the PETA  thing dosent make much sense here, we would proably not consider these animals now that they are as far as humans, now you can do THREE things with other members of your own species, including kill (holy ♥♥♥♥ they really are becoming like humans), join up with, and buy out others (Facebook would be proud), you see, buying out is pretty much the best thing to do, how I do it is, make money, buy or join others, use their ♥♥♥♥ to add to mine and ♥♥♥♥ up a weaker group, buy and join some others to get even stronger, rince and repeat till total domination. You can build ground attacker aswell as ones that sail the seas, and ones that fly (Best ones, ovbs), Its a very fun stage infact..... I prefer it to the creaure stage (Gets stabbed)
Rating:8/10 very fun

Stage 5: The final frontier SPPPPPPPPPPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACE, Your species enters the Omnicide space age and goes into space to do space things, you start off getting into your ship and riding around for a little while, upducting some hazardous ♥♥♥♥, disposing of it, saving your city, then you go into SPACE! Its time, this is easily the most in depth stage, and im too lazy too go too in-depth, What? Didnt you see the length for the 4th stage reveiw thing? this one in-depth would be MULTIPLE times longer, ♥♥♥♥ that. So heres the shorter version, you encounter many other species and using your ship and its ♥♥♥♥ton of gadgets you kill, team up with, steal from, do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want with them (Unless you get rekt). Now in this stage there is some STORY, Holy ♥♥♥♥ right? There are creatures called the Grox who are, well... evil, and they kill ♥♥♥♥ and are all big bad yadda yadda, so you become stronger, go to barren planets, harvest spice, spread your people, join other species, killt them, and its all on a ♥♥♥♥ING HUGE map, Near the center of the galaxy is where the grox reside and MAN they dont ♥♥♥♥ around, finding routes to the center while being attacked by legions of ships kicking thy ♥♥♥♥ is VERY tough, you must be very srategic, powerful, and get lucky with where routes lead, or ya know you could just join em, in the end you can reach the center and theres some ♥♥♥♥ about humans IDK.
Rating:9/10 Super amazing and easily the highlight of the entire game

Overall rating: 7.5/10
The game has its moments, and those moments are great, and it has some okay moments, it also has the tribal stage......................... as a whole the game is good and worth your time, I reccomend

Also holy ♥♥♥♥, i stopped playing at exactly 42 hours, talk about a coincedence.

helpfulness: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: March 12
												This game was my childhood back when it was popular (Rip Spore community), it will always be my favourite game. You can play god and create your own creatures and play as them through the Cell Stage (Your creature begins its story as a cell in the water), then to Creature Stage (Your creature evolves and grows legs, moves onto the land and becomes either a killing machine or a friendly diplomatic species), to Tribal Stage (Your creature discovers fire and learns to use tools, and thus begins the Tribal Stage where you have to either fight or befriend other tribes to evolve), to Civilization Stage (Your creature's species evolves to the Civilization Stage which is pretty much modern today, much like tribal stage, you must either befriend or destroy every other Civilization on the planet to evolve, but this time you will have a Navy, Airforce, ect), and finally the Space Stage (Yourr creature's species evolves into the Space Stage, the most complicated stage but in my opinion the most enjoyable stage in the game, you have the ENTIRE Galaxy to explore with over 100 other alien Empires to either go to war with, or befriend and trade with. But then once you approach the center of the Galaxy, you encounter an Empire so vicious and deadly they could simply conqure the entire Galaxy with ease if they wanted to, so beware...). The DLC for this game add amazing new content that will improve your game, Galactic Adventures is the best one though ;). On steam i have about 3 hours of playtime with Spore, but at the time i had the game and DLC on disc, and i eventually got them on steam when i recently lost my spore game cases.


Rip Maxis

helpfulness: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: February 5
												There's a lot to be said for spore.

Tld;r Spore is a game that features multiple stages of life, each serving as a unique game-mode of sorts, all starring your own custom created lifeform, contending for survival against other randomly generated life form. The biggest flaw in this game is that each mode seems so short, and lacking depth.
If the worst thing I could say about this game is there's not enough of it, it could definitely have some worse flaws.



It's a really unique and enjoyable experience, with some glaring flaws. Its a game that allows the player to experience the evoulationary stage of their very own creations. It's greatest and worst feature is the various stages of life you play as. more on that later.
to describe the game, you start out with a cell that you modify and fight other cells. its an interesting sort of "big eat small" game type that last until you eventually evolve into the next stage of life. 
This next stage of life consists of creating a land walking creature using various parts consisting of heads, mouths, arms legs, and more, to fend for itself among a randomly generated selection of creatures, both gigantic and small. This stage is fun in its own merit, but eventually leads onto a tribal stage.
The tribal stage was the most fun for me, a sort of RTS village manager. You select groups of people to roam about the world and gather resources for the village. 
After this you evolve into a civilization style game, which wasn't bad at all either. You manage cities, their happiness and resource output and whatnot while conquering other cities. 
After this is a space exploration mode which I haven't played at this time (I know its been out forever!)

helpfulness: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Simply put: this game contains nearly endless amounts of character customization, and that is why I continue to come back to it over and over. Let your imagination be your guide. You can literally spend 100% of your playing time (like I often do, myself) just designing a multitude of different creatures, vehicles (land, sea, and space) and buildings as well. The game reminded me a lot of Black and White, which I used to play near-obessively when I was younger. 

There's more to the game than just customization and character design, of course. Following the evolutionary story mode itself presents all sorts of interesting scientific, biological, and sociological mechanics. As a gamer, it's the ultimate sense of creative control to supervise and influence a creature's growth and development, along with all the cultural and societal changes that go along with it. It's just so enthralling to raise a creature from infantile stage as a microbe, all the way to a prim-and-proper gentleman of a monster.

Posted: March 23
												It was a great game in its prime, but since EA stopped giving a ♥♥♥♥ about the entire project, Maxis died, and no one actually patches the game anymore - many game-breaking glitches will erase all of your progress in a snap (as Autosaves simply don't exist in game.)

I don't reccomend the game whatsoever in its current state, but I certainly would have 3 years ago. Get it while on sale for when it's less than 10 dollars, but otherwise - stay far away. $20 is a lot to pay for something that barely runs on any Modern PC.

It's a huge shame, too. Back when it was still being updated and cared about by the developers, Spore was possibly one of the best creature-based games you could get.

body:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												Fantastic game that I loved back when it first came out and I love it still. 

Basically it's a mixed genre game. When you start it you have casual amoeba swimming game. Then you evolve and go to land where you go around eating fruits or other animals until you advance to tribal stage. Tribal stage becomes a kind of a lightweight RTS where you attack other tribes, create tools, equip them to your tribe members. After advancing to Civilization age, you start to build cities, defenses, vehicles (land, air, naval) and it's even more of RTS. And then you go into space... :) 

The best part of the game is definitely Creature Creator though. It's easy to use and you can make  many different cute creatures, only your imagination is the limit. Spore is a nice game, and additional pack add to the game but are optional.

You can even play with the music and change it during gameplay (different beats and stuff).

It's not the best game ever, but I can recommend it without any problems, especially if you're into building stuff (Sims, Sim City...) 

	Graphics: 	★★★★★	Sound: 	★★★★☆	Gameplay: 	★★★★☆	Music: 	★★★★☆                    	Overall: 	★★★★☆

body:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Very interesting game to play...really brings out your creative side. When you first start playing, your first reaction is usually, "Awwww! It's so cute!" or, "Oh my god It's going to eat me!" Let me say that this game is very realistic, and if you love animals, or "creatures" you should surely choose to be an herbivore. You choose from Carnivore, Herbivore, and Omnivore. Sometimes you'll say, "Ugh, there's too much going on!" or, "Give me a break!" But in the end things will calm down and you will begin enjoying the game a lot more once you get the hang of it and what to do and what not to do...the easiest way, and the hardest way. Once you get to space though, the game's pace slows down considerably. You get into kind of a routine and begin doing the same thing over and over again. Some quit at that point, and just keep creating games and stopping at space, but if you get past the more boring or slow-paced parts, it gets fun and "not-so-boring." All in all, if you like a game with plenty of chances to show off your creativity, I would definitely recommend this game.

helpfulness: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: January 12
												I enjoyed this game. I recommend buying the DLC for it as well though, because the Galactic Adventures DLC adds a lot. You could do without the other one though, but you might as well get it too if you have the money. 

(read no further if you don't want to know what happens as you progress.)

You start off on a planet of your choosing. From here you get to start off as a microscopic creature where you can evolve over time by either eating what I assume is algae, or other creatures. From this, paths branch off. You evolve into a mindless animal, who either tries to make friends with other creatures, fights others, or both. Then you evolve again into a tribe, where the same principles apply.  The only sad part is that you can't choose to be an underground civilization, or one that dwells in trees, underwater or on top of mountains. You can choose to give your creature wings though, if you'd like them to "fly". It's sort of just gliding, due to the fact that you can only flap your wings about 5 times or something like that.

The next stage of evolution brings you to city life, where you can either choose to dominate other nations economically, religiously, or through war. Once you've dominated all of the other nations, you advance yet again to the space stage. It's basically the same thing all over again, but in space with spaceships. That's not just it though. In space you get a variety of different missions in which you can colonize planets, eradicate diseased creatures, and even elevate tribal civilizatons!

That's not just it though. You get to create basically everything from your creature (which you can change until you get the later stages), to the buildings in which they live and work. Not only that, but you get to create their land vehicles, air vehicles, and boats. Then once you get to the space stage you get to create the spaceship model that your whole empire uses. 

If you want to play smart during the city and space stages, you can micromanage some of your cities to gain more income. Income is used to purchase vehicles during the city stage, and upgrades for your ship during the space stage. You get simple money during the city stage, but in the space stage, cities produce spice. You can sell the spices that are produced for a lot of money, if you can find the right person to sell them to.

Your goal is to reach the center of the galaxy, for who knows what might be there? But many obstacles stand in your way. Deal with them how you wish, because there are multiple ways to get there. Make friends, or dominate others to bring your rule to the whole galaxy. It's up to you. Just remember that everyone needs allies, or just really big guns. 

Lastly. The game is really monotonous in my opinion. But I like those sorts of games. If you're not a fan of monotonous tasks then you might not be a fan of this game in particular.  

Despite my annoyances with this game, I still enjoyed it a lot. Especially the missions that the DLC had to offer. I'd give this game a solid 7/10

Posted: March 9, 2016
												[Clocked in only 5 hours because I transferred to the galactic launcher but finished my first playthrough using only Spore features not galactic ones]

It's a very enjoyable game especially if you love civilization games. Here you start as a freakin single celled organism.

What I love with the early stages of the game is that your creature evolves from that single celled organism to whatever the ♥♥♥♥ you want to go with until tribal age.

I must say tribal stage up to space age the game changed for me, you stopped evolving and instead start using clothes.

Spage Age I must say is pretty freakin huge!!! So huge I can't explore it all and that's just a single galaxy.

As you go further in your own civilization you notice less and less species surround you (extiction is common even in outer space because of sentient beings being ♥♥♥♥♥)

Recommendations:
You should grab Galactic Adventures expansion as it becomes bland after exploring different sectors.
If you want the online feature to work, put the game product code you have on steam (you can get it on the CD key of your game [library->games->spore->CD key]) and put it on origin (Origin->add game->put the product code). (there's not much with the online feature though)

Regret:

I didn't get to kill humans!

helpfulness: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
body:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												I do rather love this game, but I won't recommend it.

I remember back when it was still in development and little by little sneak peeks were shown and it looked amazingly awesome... and then when it came out it (like so many other games) had been significantly dumbed down for a less complex more mainstream gameplay. Even so there was (and still is) a huge amount of delight to be had in raising your creatures from single celled organisms, chosing their skills by rewriting their DNA from generation to generation until they become civilized and then developing them into the endgame (space exploration) via technological advances.

So why no recommendation?

Well for a start the game is just outright unstable. The general instability just doesn't seem to be fixable. Everywhere I looked I found it was just an accepted side effect of running the game. So it will crash. And it doesn't autosave. So you must save often. And if you screw up and save after it's begun breaking it will destroy that save game and make it forever unloadable. It's also been ditched by EA so it won't be being fixed.

The actual evolutionary stages (barring the last) are just too plain short. I wanted to spend hours on each stage but you zoom forwards, even if you go the completionist route and stick around until you've done every last thing you can. The combat is not great, the social minigame is read a cue and then press one of four buttons (creature stage) three buttons (tribal stage) oh we got rid of the buttons just click on it already (civ stage)

The final space stage is huge and is where you will will either spend most of your time, or where you will get quickly fed up and return to the start to create more creatures. There is literally an entire galaxy to take over including a race of extremely unfriendly borg *cough* sorry, I mean Grox towards to the centre. Your creature, that you poured so much time and attention into is replaced by a spaceship and it all gets a bit meh.... Galactic Adventures does try to address this but not well... (I'll deal with that on it's own though).

Initially you will ooooh over the creature creator. Eventually you will be frustrated by it's limitations and the relatively restrictive set of main parts. The inability to set a gender/voice for your creature is most evidenced when you create something female looking and it talks like a brawny guy or something cute and sounds like it's just waiting to eat you for breakfast. There are a huge number of really minor fixes that could have been added to this that would have provided some huge quality of life improvements for this game... but despite them being suggested over and over again when the game's developers were still active, they were unfortunately never addressed.

I still love Spore. It holds a very special place in my heart, but I can't recommend it. If you still fancy it despite its issues then you'll probably have a great time with it. I'd love to see a sequel - some of the things that were cutting edge when this came out are much more developed now and it could be awesome... unlikely, but still...

body:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												At first I was going to get this game just to say that No Man's Sky is the off brand version of this. But as I started to play the game I then realized of how much of a great game this is. In Spore you get to progress froma a simple unicellular organism and gradually progress to the early stages of the human and eventually surpasing the human technology is the space stage of the game. You get to extend your creativity considering that you have the potential to create and evolve your creature, and later even design your own vehicles and buildings. This has many different games inside of it: cell stage being like a more graphically instive version of agar.io (Btw I never knew that it looks like agar.io took there idea from spore), the survival aspect of the land stage, the real time strategy aspects of both the tribal and civilization stage, and finally the unlimited diplomatic and warring space stage. Incredible game.

Posted: June 7, 2014
												I really tried to love this game. It is cute, funny, open-ended, and explores new grounds for videogames. If anything, it is admirable. But is it fun? The mechanics in every evolutionary stage are rather shallow and repetitive, the strategy components are severly limited and the action components reduced to a few button presses once in a while. Exploration falls flat too since the procedural planets are boring and samey.
The draw of this game for many seems to be the character creator, as evident by the slew of creature videos on youtube, and it is entertaining for a while, but cannot hold my attention for long.
In the end, it is suprisingly... boring.

body:
Posted: October 2, 2013
												If ever there was a game that divided opinion, Spore is it! While i can see why it frustrated a lot of people by taking the relatively cutesy path rather than being a genuine look into genetically creating different creatures, it still gives you a huge amount of options when it comes to making your own creations. The second level is where you really get to flex your creativity and is without doubt the best level in the game. It does rather tail off as you get further into it, especially the fifth stage (space travel), but when you feel like a break from the missions themselves, you can simply head back into the creature creation section and create an entire planet's worth of creatures. If you should find this at a sale price, i would recommend it then, but at full price... maybe not.

body:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!

- Serves 4
- 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook
- 325 calories / serving
- Healthy

INGREDIENTS:

- 1 orange, zested and juiced
- 2tbsp soy sauce
- 2tbsp sesame oil
- 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli
- 5cm (2in) piece root ginger
- 1tbsp sunflower oil
- 1 garlic clove, finely sliced
- 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced
- 150g Straight To Wok Noodles
- 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices

METHOD

Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.

Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.

Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.

Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.

Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

body:
Posted: March 23
												I actually like this game quite a bit, honestly, though mostly for Nostalgia reasons and the Creature Builder specifically

Good Parts
- you can make aliens of your own design and casually Play God

- It's pretty cute - the graphics aren't super realistic and thus haven't suffered too bad with aging, at least aesthetically

- This might just be a personal thing bcs I'm a sucker for worldbuilding/storywriting but it's fun to sort of evolve your little alien dude(s) into an empire and like,,, make up their history based on what happens

- This game is actually moddable, though be warned bcs it involves dropping files Directly into the game's data folder and you can't share creations made with modded parts

- It's also kinda fun to just poke around w/ the data sometimes and mess around w/ the Startup Conditions to unlock Hidden Developer Creators (the Flora and Cell Editors, for example)

Bad Parts
- It gets really, really repetitive after a while

- A lot of people (myself included) have a hard time getting the graphics to actually 'function' and register that you've set them on 'High' - I suspect this is because this game is from like just before the 2010's so it might not know how to run on modern hardware. There's a mod/fix for this somwhere if you go googling but i haven't gotten it to work

- There's quite a few bugs but *most* of the major game breaking ones have been fixed for ages.

- I have no idea if the Steam version of this has the DRM that it started with - if it does this is a Very Bad Part

- The online function is ♥♥♥♥ed on the Steam version - you have to register the game with Origin to get it to go online (though fortunately you do NOT have to buy it again - just register the CD key into it and you're good. You also don't have to bother w/ Origin after this and can never touch it again)


Despite the negatives outweighing the positives, I'm still gonna mark this as Recommended as it's a pretty fun game I feel.
EDIT TO ADD I'd still wait for it to be on sale to buy it - it's an Alright game but $20 USD for the base game + the DLC is quite a lot and when it's on sale it averages to $15 USD for all three items.

body:
Posted: November 10, 2016
												Spore is a fantastic game, whether I'm playing the full game from cell to space, or just creating a fantastic creature with my 5 year old niece. Spore is both user-friendly and appropriate for all ages and I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone.


There is only one thing I would change about this game, and this is a feature that only I am likely to care about. I want it to be possible to type more for the descriptions of the creatures and their vehicles and I want it to be possible to type descriptions for individual cities on their planets. I like to create a lot of backstory for the creatures and vehicles in my game because I want to tether the game to reality. In an effort to do this I've taken to documenting the various wars, city foundings, vehicle creations race extinctions etc. on a piece of paper. I set a timer on my phone to keep track of the "years" that have passed in the game and keep a detailed log of my civilization's history every 5 "years" from start to finish. It would be easier if I could record more info for each creature and for each city on every planet, it'd certainly save my wrist from arthritis later in life.
